Reduced to a ballad farce in 1768 and produced as "Flora, or, Hob in the well."
Reproduction of original in Huntington Library.

div.p: As it is Acted at the NEW THEATRE IN Little Lincoln's-Inn-Fields BY His Majesty's Servants.
Written by Mr. THO. DOGGET, Comedian.
LONDON, Printed for Sam. Briscoe at the Corner of Charles-street, in Russel-street, Covent-Garden; Sold by R. Wellington, at the Lute in St. Paul's Church-yard; R. Parker at the Royal-Exchange. 1696.

☞ There is in the Press and will be speedily Publish'd, Mr. Dennis's Miscellany of Poems, with several Select Translations from the Ancient Poets: Also, The Passion of Bibblis, Translated into English, By Mr. Dennis. 〈…〉

div.head: TO THE Illustrious and Truly Noble Prince JAMES, Duke, Marquess, and Earl of Ormond in England and Ireland; Earl of Ossory, and Viscount Thurles; Baron of Arclo; Lord of the Regalities and Liberties of the County of Tiperary; Baron of Lanthony; Earl of Brecknock; Chancellor of the Vniversity of Oxford, One of the Lords of the Bed-Chamber to His Sacred Majesty, Knight of the most Noble Order of the Garter; and One of His Majesty's most Honourable Privy Council.
div.p:
I Know what I ought to expect from this Presumption, but the assurance I had of your Graces Goodness to forgive me, made me suffer my Inclinations to get the better of me, and beseech your Protection for this poor Play, that has but little else to recommend it to the World, the satisfaction I had to see the little Success it undeservedly met with from the Town, gave me not so great pleasure as I
have to see your Graces Name fix'd to the Dedication; not that I Pride my Self upon any imaginary Desert; but the occasion it gives me of doing the Duty of an Englishman, from whom all that's due to the Preserver of his Country, shou'd be paid to your Grace; this, I confess, ought to be my Task, I own my Obligation, tho' I cannot pay it, nor am I much concern'd at it, since a better Pen than mine will find it a Duty too difficult to be Just in; and the generality of Mankind, I'm sure, will think me in the right, not to prophane your Noble Character, by endeavouring to describe it, which wou'd betray my Ignorance, more than the Publishing this piece of Folly will do, which cost me more Time (and Trouble) to get Acted, than did to Write it except one Act of it, which I wrote three Years ago,) As for its Faults, one of them is, I hear, that it is Obscene, I'm sorry it shou'd appear so, I'm sure I never design'd it, and I believe it will
be hard to find a Comedy with less in it; those that have the clearest Reputation, have more Reason to blush for that Sin, than this has; I own there's a scarcity of that which some call Wit, and what many Authors in this Age run mad after, endeavouring to produce it out of every bodys Mouth, whether it belongs to their Character or no, still losing the Man to goe out of the way for a Jest; 'tis what I shall never labour for, (either in Writing, if I were capable, or Acting;) for he that will make Nature his Study, will find more Charms in it, and a more certain way to Applause, than can be produc'd from any abortive Conceit, which at best, can but repay him with a loud Laughter from the Multitude, who shou'd be pleas'd, I own, but not at the expence of the Author, or the Actors Reputation, nor the Displeasure of the Judicious, who I hope will not condemn this Play from the appearance it had upon the Stage, where it suffer'd
in the Acting. By the Industrious Care of whom, was so visible to the Audience, I shall spare any further Reflexion at this time, which could chiefly be spent in begging your Grace's Pardon, for presuming so unworthily to write my self,

closer.signed: Your Grace's most Humble, Faithful and Obedient Servant, THO. DOGGET.

div.head: PROLOGUE
Spoken by Mrs. BARRY.
div.l: NEW Plays as well as Guineas fall of late,
Like Addle Plotters hurried to their Fate,
And yet our Ben wou'd needs be Plotting too,
But only Plotted for himself and you;
But yet I fear he will not please to day,
Alas! 'tis a meer out-of-fashion Play;
No Bawdy in't to make the Ladies Glow,
Nay, what is worse, the Play's without a Beau;
No Chit-Chat Repartee, nor Raillery,
Such as Masks sell Sins within the Gallery;
Stuff learnt by Rote, pass with you for Sence,
Brought here by Wits, and by Fools carry'd hence,
Nay, he has to day, spar'd min' honest Citt,
Who's Holiday Halfe Crown seats him i'th' Pit,
And Laughs when he's abus'd, because 'tis Wit;
Thus all he doe's but Politickly spare,
He fears to Bite, yet hardly can forbear,
The Poet wou'd be at you, if he might,
Did not the Player deter him from the Fight;
He Draws on your side, Swears you shall not frown,
The Comick Vein shall keep the Cynick down,
'Twixt you and him no Quarrel yet has been
If now he ere's, he'll freely own his Sin;
Nay, what's more strange, he will repent on't too,
But not as other wretched Scriblers do:
Attempt to mend, yet trouble still the Age,
Confirm them Blockheads, and Confound the Stage.

div.head: EPILOGUE,
Spoken by Mr. Betterton.
div.l: THE Careful Pilot, when he Views the Shelf
Where others have been lost, secures himself;
The Cautious Robber from that road abstains,
Where his unlucky Comrade hangs in Chains;
Thus all, except the Brothers of the Quill,
Take Early Warning by another's ill.
Writing's the Fatal Rock, on which has split
Many a Stout, and well-built Man of Wit;
And yet there's not a Sculler but shall Dare
To venture his weak, rotten Cock-boat there,
Bless me! What Wits might some Men be to th'Sight;
Wou'd they be rul'd, and neither Talk, nor Write;
For here's the Mischief of the Poet's trade;
He must be born a Wit, as well as made;
A Native, inbred spark of Heavenly heat,
In ev'ry Vein, in ev'ry Pulse must beat:
Nor will indifferent Writing do the feat,
For Poetry allows no Middle State.
No so-so Plays will do, no pretty-well,
You fail if you but Moderately excell;
It must be Heaven all, or else 'tis Hell.
Criticks are Heralds, that deny one blot
To be of Honour in a Poet's Coat:
'Tis time and labour thrown away in all,
But they that do perceive an inward Call;
And by the Orthodox none ought to be
Admitted to this Sacred Ministry,
Less then a Dryden, Congreve, Wycherly.
These Matters running in our Author's head,
He vows to me have almost made him Mad;
To know so well the Strictness of the Rule,
And yet to write; Incorrigible Fool!
Yonder he stands in Sad and Doloful Case,
Waiting the Judgment you shall please to pass;
I see he beckons to me, to intreat
That you'd be Merciful as you are Great:
Almighty Criticks, you his Judges sit;
If you consent he shall set up a Wit,
He swears he wont be prouder for't a Bit.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: SIR, Here's a Letter for you.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: A Letter, Let me see it.

body.p: I arriv'd this Day at London, and to Morrow, purpose for Gloucester: where, if after Three Years Travel, I can find my Friend what I left him; I cannot think my Self Vnhappy, how unfortunate soever I may seem to the World.

sp.p:
I wish Ned, it were in my Power to make thee as happy, as it was in thy Father's to make thee miserable; thou should'st find a better Welcome here from thy Friend, then thou wilt from a Dead Sire, and departed Acres, Sirrah, go to Sir Thomas Testies, and see if he's
at home, and at leisure to receive an Hours Conversation.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Franck Friendly.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Ned Woodvill.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What Acknowledgments shall I make my Stars for letting me live to see once more, the Man that's nearest to my Heart?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: There let me grow; till want of Friendship makes me unworthy, of the Place— I was just now Reading your Letter, and by that, did not expect to see you these two Days; How came you so soon?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I design'd to come in the Stage-Coach, but finding no other Company but an old talkative Woman, and two over-grown Boys, I chose rather than be coop'd up with Old Age and Ignorance, to ride Post, and run the hazard of breaking my Neck upon Hackney Jades: that have, I think, disjointed every Limb of me.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I wish Ned after the fatigue of thy Journey, I cou'd Entertain thee with something wou'd divert thy present pain, and prove a Cordial for the future; for the News I have to tell thee, I fear will disorder thy whole Frame, and make thy Mind as distemper'd as thy Body.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Say'st thee so, prithee out with it at once; for I am Arm'd against the worst that can befall me; my Life, which is the last and only thing Fate can now take from me; I see in no Danger, as for any other misfortune, there can come none so great as what is past.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I know not what you have met with abroad; but the greatest you are to expect here, is the News of your Father's Death, who departed a Fortnight since; but before he left the World, took care to make you a younger Brother to his Extravagancy, which has left you ne'r a Groat, for he play'd the last Game with the last stake, and Died, leaving hardly enough to Bury him.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: This I heard at London, and expected it long before: for when he sent me abroad, it was only that I might not be a Curb to his Will, which was as unbounded as his Lusts, that t wou'd be obey'd in all those Vices his younger Years ough to have been asham'd of; but the Age we live in is so perverted, that Old Men pursue the Vanities of Youth (taking up the Cudgels they lay down) and fumble with those Debauches, young Men grow weary of.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Thou say'st true, Ned; but I wish thou hadst not experienc'd it so much at thy own Cost.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: So do I Frank; but since it was in my Power to prevent it, it shall not now be my fault to repine at it; the Old Gentleman cou'd not 'a chosen a better time to put me to my Shifts, since the War gives me so Glorious an opportunity to try what Fortune has in store for me.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Fortune! Prithee what canst thou hope from Fortune, with Bullets flying about thy Ears, that cou'd Buffet thee so unmercifully in the time of Peace; Had'st thou a Friend indeed who had Interest to get thee a Commission, that had Authority in it to keep thee out of Harms way, thou might'st hope as much as another Man; But as thou hast nothing to prefer thee, but a comely Figure of Six Foot high, thou oughtst to look for nothing more, then after the first Volley, to chance on a clean place to measure thy Length on, without spoiling thy Cloaths.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Prithee Frank, What Commands are those that have Power to awe a Bullet, for till now, I never heard a Cannon made any distinction.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: True Ned, if we come in their way; but I've known some Men, whose Actions were above being question'd, step aside when Danger fac'd 'em, but if their Enemies (meeting with the worst of it) have been forc'd to turn their Backs, have fall'n in like Lions, to scramble for Honour, and come home laden with as much as he that deserv'd most.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p:
I must confess we have too frequent Examples
of this kind; however it shall not keep me from doing my best to serve my Country, nor make medespair of Success.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: You do well to hope the best; it doubles our misfortunes to afflict our Selves with the Apprehension of 'em; which sometimes make 'em look more dreadful than they are in themselves.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: That will never be my fault, for disappointments are so frequent with me, that I shou'd look for nothing else, did I not believe all things must have an end, one time or other.
How now, Did not I send you to Sir Thomas Testies?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, I was going as you commanded me; and met his Man by the way, coming with a Message to you, and he is now without, waiting to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: This Old Knight (Ned) was a Citizen of London, but being weary of his Vocation, and willing to keep a young Wife to himself, is come to inhabit here, upon an Estate which he has lately purchas'd; part of it was your Fathers: he has one only Daughter by a former Wife, whom Nature has been very bountiful to, she wants no Charm to make her Self Ador'd, and hath found that way to my Heart, which none of her Sex cou'd ever do before. There is a Neece (Ned) is equally deserving, and would be equally desirable, did not Love to shew his Power, byass my Affections: Come, thou shalt go with me and see them, if thy Journey has not fatigu'd thee too much.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Never to hinder me from the Company of a pretty Woman Frank; that Temptation is more prevalent with me than any other, Nature can be liable to: But at present I must deny my self that satisfaction; I hear the Post goes hence within these Two Hours, and I have Business obliges me to write by the first opportunity; but let my Man go with you to acquaint my himself with the way; and I will come to you, as soon as I have dispatch'd Jack, wait of Mr. Friendly, and come back quickly.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: 'Tis very well, Your Servant; Come back.

div.head: SCENE II. A Room at Sir T. Testie's.
div.stage: Enter Sir Thomas Testie and Lucia.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Niece, come hither,— Come hither, I say, and shut the Door.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Bless us! What's amiss in the State, that I must be Closeted.— The Door is lock'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Very well; Come hither then:— Hark'ye, who am I?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Who are you, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Ay; whom am I?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You are my Unkle, Sir, I think.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Am I no more than your Unkle? your Father thought me worthy of a better Title, when he made me your Trustee, and by that means impower'd me to make you a Beggar, had I not been your very good Friend as well.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Sir, you have been more than I cou'd hope for— Nor shall you ever find me wanting in those Acknowledgments your Goodness has oblig'd me to pay you, for your extraordinary Care of me, when I was left young and unable to take any for my self.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: 'Tis very well; Why then, since occasion now presents, wherein you may in some measure requite my Love, and discharge your Duty, I expect you shall be sincere with me, and Answer me directly;— When was Mr. Friendly last with my Daughter?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: I say, When was Mr. Friendly last with my Daughter?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: To the best of my Remembrance— Sir— I won't— be positive— but—

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p:
But— No, no hold— hold— lookd'ye see, If I catch you stumbling, or endeavouring by your Female Devil's Wit at a pinch, to cast a blind upon my
Understanding, I shall conclude you as bad as she, and both alike shall share my Resentment. Therefore come, I say, and Answer directly to the Question, for I will know it, and from you Huswife— You that are her Confident, as you call it,— Her Help-Mate to Iniquity: What, because I am Old, and can't go withour a Staff, you think I'm Blind and can't See your Roguery without a pair of Spectacles,— but I have found you out Mistress, I have so.—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Found us out; I hope, Sir, you don't think that she wou'd Act, or I Assist her, in any thing, that might blame her Conduct to Mr. Friendly, who you know to be a worthy Gentleman, and one, I'm sure, I have heard you say, you had rather dispose of her to, then any Gentleman in the Country; and if so, I don't know why I should conceal their being together, since their designs are Honourable.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: How— What— Designs, and Honourable— What— without my Knowledge— without first consulting me— that am her Father— whose sole Right it is to dispose of her Person; and dares he, without my Leave, my Consent to Authorize his Pretensions, make Love to her, under my roof? Were he a Prince, and wou'd Endow her like a Queen, and shou'd but think of such a thing, without my Licence; I wou'd Lock her up till the Green-Sickness had made her Eat her passage to him thro' the Wall, tell her so, d'ye hear—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Indeed old Gentleman, you wou'd a found neither Locks nor Bolts cou'd have held her,— Had she not been disoblig'd by his making you acquainted with his Love, for she is such a Friend to Disobedience, that she thought your being privy to the matter, a sufficient Reason to discard him her Favour, so that now I hope you may have a very Dutiful Child of her.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Was not that my Father that parted from you?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: It was.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Was he in Humour?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes, a very ill one, at the news of your proceedngs with Mr. Friendly; If you think you shall dye for Love Floria, you may prepare your self a Halter, and swing to Elizium as soon as you please, for your Father hath forbid the Banes; had he been first acquainted with your Lovers Inclinations, you might have eaten a Sack-Posset after a Matrimonial Grace together, according to Custom; But you are now to be Lock'd up, and feed upon Chaulk and Lime, he says, till you have eaten a Passage to your Spark thro the Wall.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I'm glad to find him so resolv'd, I shall now dispose of my self to my own liking; for had he been enclin'd to the Match, I was resolv'd never to see Friendly more, for affronting my Love, by seeking me at my Father's Hands, when that had assur'd me to him before.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why, Wou'd you not have your Father have a Power in disposing you where he likes best?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Yes, if he cou'd Command my Love; But since that's decree'd by a higher Power, I must go with my Heart whether he will or no; nor shall he have any Vote where he has no right to give it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: An excellent Piece of Sophistry to incourage Disobedience.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You may call it what you please. But in following the dictate of my Passion, I obey the Power that made it; and my Duty towards Heav'n is to be consider'd before that to my Father I take it; I shall therefore Marry without his Leave or Knowledge.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why without his Knowledge?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: For the pleasure of what thou call'st Disobedience. Why thou forget'st sure that I am a Woman as thou art; the Sex that first taught it to the World, wou'dst have me degenerate?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
O, by no means, Madam; pray go on, have a care of being unjust to your Self; whatever you do; and for the better incouragement to proceed, Know, your Father
hath sent this day to Mr. Friendly to forbid him the House, or approach it at his peril.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I know it, and by the same Messenger, I bid him me et me to night at the Garden Door; I scorn the Old Gentleman shou'd have the start of me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And pray what's the business of your meeting? To contrive how you may run away with him?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: That's as he shall deserve, if he's as fond of the Vagabond Trick as my self, and will be contented to take me for my own sake, without any other Consideration—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You'll be contented to pack up your Awls; that is a clean Smock, with a Suit of Night Cloaths thrust into a Band-box, and bid Good-buoy Daddy;— Well speed thee well, since thou art resolv'd upon a mad Trick, I think indeed, thou cou'dst not have chosen an honester Fellow to play it with.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You may call it a mad Trick, but any other had been a foolish one, witness my Mother-in-law, had she been Govern'd by her own Will, my Father had wanted a Comforter in his old Age; and she had been better supply'd with one in her Youth.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Go, you're naught, I'll talk no more with you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Nay, take me with you, for if you leave me here alone, I shall think worse than I talk.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Come along then, Mad-Cap.

div.head: SCENE, Back Door of a Garden.
div.stage: Enter Lady Testie, and Betty in their Hoods and Scarfs.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Good dear Madam, don't afflict your self, since y'are bound to your Misfortune, resolve to endure it, and make your self as easie under it, as you can; your Grief will make you sick in earnest else.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
I wish it cou'd, that I might not be troubl'd to dissemble it; to keep my self from the loath'd Bed of that
old nauseous Wretch, my Husband; who not contented to Wed me to his wither'd Carkass, has also forc'd me from London from my Friends, from every thing that might give me Comfort in my Misery, to dwell here in a Country Town, where nothing is to be seen but such as himself.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, here's something better to be seen then himself;— What think you of the Gentleman you saw alight yesterday at the Inn Door, when you stood at the Window.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: O don't name him, unless thou cou'dst give me another sight of him; and yet I fear if I had my Desires, 'twou'd serve me only to beget another, and another; still succeeding, till I had ask'd my Ruine. Did you enquire who he is?

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: I did, Madam, but cannot learn; he came from London, and 'tis thought by the People of the House, he stays for Horses, to convey him farther.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Cou'd not ye have contriv'd to have spoke to him?

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: I cou'd, Madam, had you so commanded me; but 'to what end?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Nay, I know not, thô I wish he knew my Heart, and were inclin'd to take me from my Plague my Husband, who, I'm resolv'd never shall enjoy me, thô I'm sure to be the unhappiest of my Sex.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: 'Tis impossible, Madam, I think, for you to hold out much longer; you ha' kept him this Month (e'er since you were Married) from your Bed, with the pretence of Sickness, he now grows impatient, and begins to believe 'tis design'd thrô the want of Love.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I care not what he believes— ha!— Who's that yonder?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Where, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Yonder, coming down the Walk.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: 'Slife, Madam, 'tis the stranger we was talking of.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Put on your Mask.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Did not you say, you had a mind to see him, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I have, and speak to him; but he must not see my Face; but see, he makes this way.
sp.stage: Enter Woodvill, and Jack the Boy.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Boy, which is the House?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Sir, they go in at one of these Garden Doors to it; but they are so much alike, I can't go directly to it; I'll knock, if you please, at one of them, and enquire.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What's here? Women, and Mask'd, I thought Vizards had been of no use at night, out of London, where they did not serve to invite us to a Face that had a mind to be seen; Jack, when you have found Sir Thomas Testies, wait for me at the end of the Walk.

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Yes Sir—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Ladies, is not the pleasure of the Walk lost, without company?
Not to us, Sir; we think Two enough, and are best pleas'd when we are by our selves.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: If one of you has hid a different Sex under her Petticoat, I cou'd believe you; but Two Women can only talk themselves into an Imagination of a Pleasure; they can never produce without the help of one of us.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ay;— What's that, Sir, which we of our selves are not able to possess, without your assistance.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Lookyee Child, if you have an inclination to be inform'd, leave your Friend and come with me to the other end of the Walk, and I'll shew you presently.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I do nothing without her, Sir; If you can't instruct us both together, we'll not Edifie alone.

sp.speaker: Wood
sp.p: Both together;— I'll give you leave to seem as ignorant as you please, if you have a mind not to understand me; but don't put me upon impossibilities;— If you'll retire with me one at a time, I'll promise you shall be both satisfy'd, before I leave you.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: But how shall we be sore you'll keep your Promise? Have a care you don't put your self upon impossibilities.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: ‛ Egad that's true too; I think I have been a little too forward; but come my Dear, what I want in Power, you shall find I have in Will, therefore don't lose time.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Who do ye speak to?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Aye; suppose we had a mind to take you at your word, which of us wou'd you chuse first? for I don't see yet to which you are inclin'd?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Nay Gad, that I can't tell; unless you agree to pull off your Masks, you keep my Fancy in the dark.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And 'tis too light I think to shew our Faces, after the liberty we have taken— How, or which way shall I contrive to keep him? If he leaves me now, perhaps I may never see him more; and he has staid too long already, to part with him for ever; think quickly, what shall I do?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: I can't tell how to advise you, Madam, unless you take him this back way into the House with you; when we have him there, we shall have more time to consider what's best to be done.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Ha! What are they doing, drawing Cuts who shall be first serv'd; Ladies, pray let no Dispute arise between you upon my Account; I'm resolv'd to goe with her that's nearest my own temper; let the coldest Constitution withdraw, till the other and I have been a little better acquainted, and then—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Hold— Hold, Sir— Don't raise you Expectation too high, thô the freedom we have given our selves, may cause a suspicion of our Conduct, you will not find us to be what you imagine.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I'm sorry for that; Are you what you seem to be, Women?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Yes, but not fit for your Conversation, for we are Honest, yet were we willing to be otherwise, our Age wou'd want a Charm to provide for us.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p:
Honest,— and Old— What, do ye study always to my Courage, before I come to ingage— Ha!— Here's a plump smooth Arm; and your Speech
does not betray any want of Teeth; and so far I'm sure, you are Young enough.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You'r Ear has deceiv'd you then; for I want all my Teeth but three.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: If you had two less than you have, I'm sure you have a Colt's-tooth, as long as there's a Stump left; therefore that shall be no hindrance.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Hold, I say, where wou'd you have me?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Have thee, Child, why to the next Green Bank we come at: 'Tis true, the Place is not so well, as I cou'd wish it; but Love will make hard shifts.— See your Friend knows your Mind, she keeps her distance.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Forbear; and if it is in your Power to behave your self like a Gentleman, follow me, and as you shall deserve expect a Return; But first, for your Instruction, know you must put a Constraint upon your temper, and seem Virtuous, which I believe will cost you some pain to do.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Seem Virtuous What a Pox do's she mean by Cramping of me?— Hark'ye Child, do's your Friend use to task her Lovers, as Conjurers do the Devil, with things Impossible.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Whatever task she designs for you; 'tis such, I believe you'd very willingly go through, if you knew the Reward wou'd follow.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Say'st thou so; I'gad I'll endeavour to guess, to Incourage me.

l.hi: Whate'er it is; it can't but easie prove,
Enjoyn'd by Beauty, and repaid with Love.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: HOwe'en you'r pleas'd to reproach me, Madam, I beg you'll think better of my Love; than to believe it has a Thought beyond your self: 'Tis true, I ask'd you of your Father; But I ask't nothing else but you, that he might witness for me to the World how much beyond it I preferr'd you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Well; I'll not enquire any farther what your Reasons were; but whoever has me must receive me from my own Gift, and consequently without a Portion; for Sir Thomas parts with nothing that he can keep to himself; therefore, think before 'tis too late, how Love and Marriage may agree with you, where there is a Fortune wanting to support it.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I beseech you, Madam, If I am not wholly lost in your Esteem, name it not; I have Estate enough to make us both happy, if Fifteen hundred Pounds a Year, and an Unexhausted stock of Love can do it.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Well; for once I'll try to believe you; and in the mean time, take this Confession, which I did not design so soon should a spoke my Inclinations, if I am not yours on those Conditions, I here promise never to be anothers.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: O say that again; that the Sound may dwell in my Ears, and the business of my Life shall become my study to repay it.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: O Madam, Madam, Sir Thomas has been enquiring for you all over the House, and has sent me and the rest of the Servants to look for you.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Then I must leave you.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Unhappy Chance! Speak, my Soul, when shall I see you again?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I know not;— When next I hear from you, If I can, I'll send you, word, till then—

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Ten thousand Angells dwell with my Love.
Boy, where's your Master?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: I left him here, Sir, when I came to you; and he order'd me to come to him to the end of the Walk, but I can't find him.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Our staying so long, I believe, has tyr'd his Expectation. Come, let's go home.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Sir Thomas Testie and Betty.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Patience! What do'st thou preach Patience to me for, when thou know'st I have not so much left, as will stay the Roasting of an Egg.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Had you as much as wou'd go to the building of Pauls, I'm afraid you wou'd have occasion for it.

It's very true, indeed, Sir, I must needs say, but where there's no Remedy, we must bear it: Alas! my poor Lady has a double Portion of Sorrow; First from her Sickness, and next to be kept from your Embraces, for sure, Sir, whatever you are pleas'd to think, I'm confident she loves you.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Dost thou think so; I wish she'd give me a Reason to think so, for to me her sickness seems Apocryphal; she'll take nothing, though the Doctors and Apothecaries every Day send in as many Pots and Glasses, as would Kill or Cure a whole Parish.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, Her weak Stomach loaths every thing that's offer'd her, if it has but the Name of Physsick.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Why, what's to be done then?

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p:
Sir, She has to day, through my persuasion taken a Cordial to strengthen her Stomach; and if to Night
I can but get her to use something that's prepar'd for her, it will put her kindly to rest, and make her clear another Woman by the Morning.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Say'st a so, my Girl; How thou reviv'st me What is't? Prithee tell me, what it is?

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: That your Worship shall know time enough; for if it agrees with her, it must be your Care hereafter to see that she has it often, or it will indanger a Relapse; In the mean time, Sir, your best care will be to Command the Family early to Bed; for if she be disturb'd in its Operation, it may prove of dangerous Consequence.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: I'll warrant thee, my Girl, not a Dog in the House shall dare to wag his Tail after she's in her Chamber; but prithee see that she has enough of it; and if she shews any disgust in the taking of it, bid her think of me, and that for my sake she must be prevail'd upon.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Nay, If she has the Pleasure (I shou'd have) in using an Old Man as he deserves, she'll not forget ye; Though she'll have a stronger Motive to think of something else, when she's in the Arms of a Young Fellow that she likes.— Pray leave every thing to my management, and good Sir, be going early to Bed, and pray our Endeavours may prosper.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Pray— Ay, Ay; Thou needs not fear but I'll pray, and I hope my Prayers will be heard, for I am not often troublesome.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: So— I hope I've secur'd my Ladies pleasure, without the Fear of being disturb'd; Now to prepare the matter.
sp.stage: Enter Lady Testie, led in by Flora and Lucia.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh, Oh,— lead me to a Chair; Oh, Oh, — Betty, come hither.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Will your Ladiship be pleas'd to have any thing.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No, no; Nothing but a little more Air, if you please. Oh,— Oh,— where is Sir Thomas, I thought I heard him with you, when my Fit took me?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No, Madam; If you please we'll send for him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No, 'tis no matter;— My Distemper is such, it makes me fancy I see him oftner than I do.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I believe you see him oftner then you wish.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You may be sure of it; Can any Woman look upon a Husband of his Years, without fancying she's taking leave of the World; were I in her Condition, 'twou'd make me set the Sexton to Work without the help of a Physician.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh— Oh—. (aside to Betty.) What have you done with the Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: I've dispos'd him, Madam, as you bid me; but I fear it will be Impossible to conceal him there till bed time, from every body's knowledge.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I know it. Sir Thomas therefore I design shall see him, and bid him Welcome.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: 'Slife, here comes my Father, Lucia! How shall I avoid him?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: The best way as I know, is to take your Hoels, Floria.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: How now! What are you scar'd at the sight of me? Come back here Gentlewoman, come back I say, thou Pimple of the Primitive Itch; that like thy Grandmother Eve, will eat of no Fruit but what's forbidden thee; Pray, when is it forsooth, that we are to dance at your Wedding, hah?— Have you got the Man in the Mind yet, you are ready I know, let him come when he dares.

sp.speaker: Flo Sir,
sp.p: I'm never ready to do any thing I ought not to do; If I have receiv'd the Addresses of Mr. Friendly, 'twas because I thought I saw nothing in him, that you cou'd disapprove, and his Love and Fortune claim'd that return I but justly made him.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p:
God so, Madam; I beg your Pardon, get you to him then, if you think so; Go, get you gone to him then as fast as you can go; and let the Parson mumble ye together, that you may dance your Matrimonial Jigg without loss of time. Do you long to be Moulding of Cockeldebread, hah; get you out of my sight, Hussey, go; Hold, now I think again, you shall not go, you shall stay here and
hang at my Girdle like a Horn-Book, till I have learnt ye through.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: You'd sooner crack your Brains with her, Old Gentleman; that I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: But here,— here is my greatest Grief, all my other Afflictions are doubl'd and trebl'd in this one; and this will sink me to the Grave; How dost thou my Love? Is there no hopes of Comfort? Must I for ever live without the use of my self; or, like Tantalus, have the Meat at my Nose, and yet be forbid to Eat.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: We must endeavour to be satisfy'd, my Dear a little time will, I hope, restore me to my Health; you must needs think it is an equal trouble to us both, tho' my Sex forbids me to express so much of it as you do.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Say'st-a so; then I will be satisfy'd, if thou dost love me, I'll wait with more Patience than a Patriarch for thee.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: You shall not need, Sir, I hope, if my Lady will be but rul'd.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: O my Dear, this importunate Wench wou'd not let me alone, till I had promis'd to take something to night, that she had provided for me; thô I fear the very sight of it will disorder me.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: The sight of it; why, what need you look upon it, take it in the dark; and if you can but get it into your Mouth, consider the good it will do you, and I'll warrant you'll get it down, therefore pray take it.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why then I will my Dear, since you will have it so, pray come hither and lead me in; but hold, I have something to say to you first; Betty has been a very good Girle, and for that reason I will forbear to chide her, for her fault in admitting a Man to my House, with any design, without my Knowledge.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: A Man! What dost thou mean, hah? What Man, hah? What Man?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: What Man, Sir— Why— a.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Hold your Tongue, and don't go about to excuse it.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: With all my Heart; for I'm sure I'm at a loss to justifie it.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: 'Twas a fault, knowing how much Sir Thomas and I are your Friends; and wou'd rather promote a a good Husband for you; than he your hindrance.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Say you say— Lies the Game there—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: This Gentleman, my Dear (for so it seems he is, and the only Son of a very good Family) has for tun'd to fall in Love with this foolish Girl, and comes unknown to them to Court her for a Wife; therefore pray Sir Thomas, if you can be any ways assistant in forwarding the matter, do it in consideration of her faithful Service to me.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: With all my Heart — Betty— Let me see him, and his Love shall not want incouragement, and if, my Life, thou dost recover thy Health, I'll make her a Fortune that shall deserve a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Go Betty, bring him hither— (Aside.)— and be sure you caution him how to behave himself, but keep him still, in ignorance of us and our purpose.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I will, Madam.—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: What a dear Friend Dissimulation is to a Woman, how many mouldy Kisses has it sav'd my Mother-in-law, from my Fathers old brush Beard.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why, d'ye think she dissembles?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Aye, as sure as thou do'st, when you cry you'll never Marry, and had rather have me for a Bed-fellow, than a Man.
sp.stage: (Betty goes to her Lady, and whispers.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: 'Tis well they have taken pity of me, and suffer'd me to breath in a larger Room; I wish they may have Charity to reward my Sufferings, for I have been thrust into such a hole, that no body but a Beau, who fear'd being drub'd for Cuckoldom cou'd a hid himself in it.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: How! Not speak to him, say you?

sp.speaker: Bett
sp.p: I cou'd not, 'twas impossible, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p:
Odds so, a very handsome young Fellow; Sir, your Servant, y'are welcome, very welcome; and had I seen you before, and known your intent of coming hither,
your Reception ssiou'd not a been conceal'd, what ever your Love was.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Reception and Love, What a Pox does the Old Fellow mean, my Fairy Mistress, I pickt up by Moon-shine, has not brought me here, sure, to make a Jest of me: (Looking on Floria and Lucia.) Ha! there they are by this light a Couple of pretty Creatures; Now wou'd I part with any thing butmy Manhood to know which of 'em I'm first to have a Fall with; for by their Discourse, I found they had both a mind to try my strength.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I perceive by the Lovers Silence, my Unkle has put him out of Countenance.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: He looks like a likely Fellow; if he does not want a Tongue, Betty has made a good choice.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Come, Sir, you seem surpriz'd that I'm privy to this matter; don't fear, I'm a Friend to her you love, and for her sake will assist you in this Business, farther than you imagine.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Egad, may be so, and perhaps farther than I desire; I Thank you, Sir, But however you came by your Knowledge, if she that brought me here, had been as wise as she ought to be, she had known you were no more fit to be acquainted with my Business, than you are to do it.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Say you so, Sir; perhaps I mistake your Business, I thought 'twas Honourable, 'twas so represented to me; Sir, if it is otherwise, there's the Door, 'tis as wide as 'twas when you came in, you shall have no Coupling here, if you come not I God's name.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What does the old Blade mean, and who a Plague does he take me for?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Sir, as you hope to have a happy end of this Adventure, Humour my Master's mistake, and seem to be what he'd have you.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What he'd have me— What's that— I— I—
sp.stage: (Looking on the Maid, and sometimes on Sir Thomas.
sp.p:
ask your pardon— Sir,— if l've been unmannerly— I thought my Design had been conceal'd, but since it has come to your Knowledge, I hope you'll be my Friend as
you've promis'd, for there is but few I care to trust with a Secret of this Nature.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: The fewer the better; what need any body know of it, but we that are present; but to prevent what may happen if they shou'd let us come to a conclusion, What say you, will you to Bed together presently?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: With all my Heart, Sir, this Minute if you please. (Aside.) I-Gad this will be rare; I wish I knew how these witty Rogues have plotted to gain the Old Man's helping Hand, to the Friendly Office of Pimping for me. But I find my Business is not to be inquisitive; I'm only to suffer my self to be led to the Feast; and when every thing is prepar'd, then fall to.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Hold your Tongue, Huzzy, and say no more; it shall be as I'de have it—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Indeed my Dear I think she's in the right; so suddain, and at this time of Night; it will not be decent.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Decent; Fiddle Faddle; strick while the Iron's hot; many accidents fall between the Cup and the Lip; if she don't know what's good for her self, I do; she'll make me a Curt'sie for it to Morrow Morning, and Than] me; go go, presently to Amen the Clerk, and bid him bring Mr. Small Tythes, the Vicar.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: The Vicar, Sir.—

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Aye? Why?— He'll do it as well as the Parson.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I-Gad, but he shan't, Thank you.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Goe, Goe Girle, make haste, when tis done, 'tis done, you know.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Aye, and I know any thing the Parson does, is not to be undone by any body but the Hangman, and I'm not ready yet for eigher of their Noozes.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: So, my Spark has made a fine hand on't; he has spoil'd his Part by over acting it. — Betty, think of some way as you go along to bring himoff again.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: If I shou'd, I fear he'd be gravell'd again, for 'tis Impossible he shou'd find his way thus in the Dark.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p:
Now I think again, Sir— a— a— a— I must intreat you defer this matter till a Canonical hour; for I'm under an Obligation to a Deceas'd Grand-mother,
not to marry out of one; and tho Dead I durst not disobey her Commands.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Why, that's well said; I love thee the better for't: But prithee let it be suddenly.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: The sooner the better, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: What say you, to morrow Morning then.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: With all my Heart.— By that timesure I may hope to be able to expound this Riddle.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Very well. Niece and Daughter, entertain the Gentleman, while I wait on my Wife to her Chamber, and I'll be with you again presently, Sir, your Servant.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Sir, I'm yours.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Betty, hearken to their Discourse; and if any shou'd happen to our prejudice, be ready to step in, and break it off.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: I will, Madam.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I wish that Old Fellow had not taken his Wife away with him; for my Temper at this time has inclin'd my Heart more to the making of Cuckolds, than the Destruction of Maiden-heads.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Now for a formal Bow, and a set Speech; these Country Sparks approach all Women as they do their Godmothers, when they ask 'em blessing.

sp.speaker: Luo.
sp.p: I believe you'r mistaken, Floria; I fancy that Air will produce something more than you imagine.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I shou'd a fancy'd so too, if he had not made Love to my Mother's Maid.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Now the Enemy is drawn off, Ladies, I hope we come to a Close Parley again; for since I have seen your Faces, it has cost me more Pain to hold my Tongue, than 'twou'd a Maid of Forty, when she was bid say after a Parson for a Husband.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Say you so; Well, and now 'tis at Liberty, what have you to say?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p:
Nay, Gad, I think not much, for we were agreed in a manner before we came hither; and what remains now, is to be done, Child, and not said.— Come, set aside that Improper Face upon the Matter, and shew me the way to your Chamber; I know you like me, or
you wou'd not a taken so much pains to a brought me here

sp.speaker: Flo. Luc.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What a Pox do they laugh at?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Prithee Cousin, what does he mean?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nay, I must ask you that, who brought him here.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I bring him here!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Poch; You brought me here between you, and you shall share me between you as far as I can go; therefore prithee let us Understand one another without more a do

sp.speaker: Flo. Luc.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: You may laugh, Ladies; but if you force me away with your Jest, I'gad you shall cry for me, before you have me again.

sp.speaker: Flo. Luc.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Good, Sir, have a Modester Opinion of your self, than to believe the loss of you wou'd cost either of us one Tear, though we were those very kind Fools you say we are.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: No indeed, Sir; We are not so inamour'd of your sweet Sex, (thô we must own here's a Scarcity in this Place) to weep for any Man, thô he promis'd more to recommend himself, than any of your Mothers making.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Pray Madam, don't disparage my Mother's Huswifery; I think this Leg with the true proportion of my Body, shews she made as good Instruments to raise Succession to the Family, as any Dutiful Wife in the Parish; and let me tell you, if you were not worse than an errant Widow, you'd say so too, but 'tis no matter; such as I am, I shall find somebody will know what it is to be thankful for me, and for them only will I keep my self, and so Ladies your Servant.

sp.speaker: Flo. Luc.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Perhaps you think I won't go.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Sure he's Mad.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p:
I believe so too; Good, Sir, let me ask ye one
Question. You seem to be very well acquainted with us; Pray how long is it since, and where did our acquanitance first begin?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Come along with me, and I'll shew thee the Place presently; and as forgetful as you seem to be now, if I don't give thee Reason to Remember it these Nine Months, I'm a Capon.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: I'm afraid I've staid a little of the longest. Sir, perhaps you'r weary with riding, and had rather be a-bed; if you please I'll light you to your Chamber.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He does talk indeed as if he wanted sleep.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Madam, I believe my Lady will want you and Madam Lucia's help, for she's grown exceeding ill.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I rather believe, Gentlewoman, you want our absence; which shou'd we afford you, I fear will give you occasion to be worse than you ought to be

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: Pray, what d'ee mean, Madam?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Your pretended Lover here wears too thin a Disguise to pass upon us, thô he has upon my Father; a Gentleman of his Sense is seldom so fond of Marriage, to have such an honourable design upon a Chambermaid.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Ha; what's the Meaning of this? I honourable designs upon any body!

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: I hope, Madam, you don't think I'd admit of any Thoughts but what are so, I'm sure, Sir, if you have any you never own'd them to me, therefore pray Winking on him. don't let your Carriage be such as may make the Young Ladies, or any body else believe I wou'd suffer any evil Proceedings; and if you think so, you'l find your self mistaken, I'll tell you that, for all I'm a Poor Servant, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: The Devil's at Work for me, I find, by this Wenches winking, but what I must do or say to help the matter forward, I'm a Dog if I can tell.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p:
Sir, my Wife continues very ill, and I cannot wait on you, but I hope you'll be so kind to Command
my House however; Betty, see the Gentleman has every thing that's fit to make him welcome: Come Girls, come here's no business for you, therefore leave the Lovers to themselves, come.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Sir, be pleas'd to leave us here; and we'll wait upon you in a moment.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: To what end forsooth?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Sir, we have some reasons to suspect this Gentleman's pretensions to Betty; and before, we leave him alone with her, my Cousin and I will enquire, if you please, a little more into the Truth.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Humph— You enquire— What— What would you enquire? ha!— What wou'd you enquire?— What a mighty concern you have for every Morsel that goes by your own Mouth; You enquire— You have such an Itch to know how matters stand towards Matrimony; you are for examining every body how 'tis with them— Pray walk in, Pray do,— You enquire.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Harkee Damsel, you that can tell, now the Coast is clear— Pray let me know what's my business here; and and how am I to be employ'd to Night?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: What your Business will be, Sir, I can only guess; but mine is to light you to a good Bed, and clean Lumen; a Bed-fellow I can't promise you, but shou'd you happen to find one you like, I hope you'll remember your Benefactor.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Well hinted that I will, and to assure thee I'll keep my word, there's earnest for thee;— But may not I guess who this may be?

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: That you may, Sir, and be deceiv'd;— But if you hit the Nail on the Head, I must not tell you.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Come, thou shalt tell me; and tell me against thy Will; I'll force thee to't—

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: I must not indeed, Sir, but if you'll follow me, I will endeavour to carry you, where you shall inform your self.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Wilt thou, that's better still;

l.hi: Sure at the last we shall this Clew unwind,
At least the Ball if not the Bottom find.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I Wish I cou'd guess where my Friend is: If we were in London, I shou'd believe some Petticoat Companion had pick't him up; but here's no Traders; and for any other Woman, he has not had time to fit her for his use: — Robin, bid that Country-fellow without come to me.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Hob, Can'st thou carry this Letter to Sir Thomas Testies House for me?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Do so; and give it to Madam Flora; but take care no Body sees you deliver it.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Yes, Sir,— But must I car it to Night, 'tis very dark?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: You must go immediately.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: I hope Sir, there's no difference between you and Sir Thomas?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Why do'st thou hope so?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Why truly, Sir, I do hear there is; and if so, I shan't greatly care to meddle or make between Friends, that I must tell you, for 'tis but an unthankful Office; besides, you know Sir Thomas is a Man that's very curst; and if he do's but respect I concern my self between you, may hap he may take the Law of me.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Pish, the Law of thee, no, no, I'll secure thee from any harm.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Very well, Sir, very well, that's as much as I can desire; but pray don't take unkindly what I say; for you know no Man is willing to bring himself into a primunire if he can help it.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: No, no, prithee be gone.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: I will, Sir, I will— for— for— Pray, Sir, be pleas'd to read the Subscription for me.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, how I'm tortur'd with this foolish Fellow? and I can send no Body else, without being suspected; don't trouble thy self with the Superscription, but deliver it as I bid thee.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Very good, Sir, very good;— 'tis main dark; Wou'd it not do as well, Sir, if I shou'd car it in the Morning?— I had rather carry it in the Morning.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Why truly, Sir, I'll tell you;— At the lower end of Sir Thomas's Orchard, one of our poor Neighbours, being in a dispariging condition, has gone and Hang'd himself:— Now there is some does say who have seen him, how that he walks by Night in several shapes.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: What, and so you're afraid, are you?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: No indeed, Sir, I'm not afraid, I thank Providence, I defie the Devil, and all his Works.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: A Pox upon thee then, get thee gone.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Tho' I must tell you, I have a great conceit that he will appear to me; for you must know, to Morrow the Crowner's Quest do's sit upon him, whereof, de'e see, I am to be one; and who knows but he may have something upon his Spirits that may make him break his Mind to me; and if so— Let me tell you, I'm afraid it will make a bad Day for some Body: For if Sir Thomas had kept his Fences whole, may hap this Man had never been tempted to 'a gone into his Ground to 'a Hang'd himself: But be it as it will, I'll do your Business for you; therefore pray take you no care, Sir.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Prithee about it then.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Aye, aye, I'll warrant you, I'll warrant you, don't trouble your self no further.

div.head: SCENE II. Room, Table, Book and Candle.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Adventures of this kind, that look with the face of a Reward, make Expectation great and uneasie; but mine has been so often jilted, since I've been here, I begin to wish it Morning, that I might go home and laugh at my self for my damn'd impertinent Curiosity— Yet methinks this Business shou'd not end so, if this Virgin, Wife, or Widdow, or what the Devil she is I know not, (that do's trick me) shou'd suffer me to sleep to Night, with a bare Pillow in my Arms; may she have the Curse of always lying alone, and never know the use of a Bedfellow. [Sees a Book on the Table.] How now, what's here, a Book? As I'm a Whore-master, an errant Pray'r-Book: Let me see what Title do's it bear — The Crums of Comfort— A Plague of your Dyet;— Is that feeding for a Gentleman?— Now have I a good mind to read and be Converted; fall a singing of Psalms, and disturb the whole Family;— But that's to mortifie my self now I think on't; I'll e'en go to Bed, and try to forget 'em.
sp.stage: [Puts out the Candle, and is going to Bed.
Enter Lady Testie, in a Night-Gown.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: So, now the Candles out, I may with safety venture:— Sir,— Sir,—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Ha! Who's there?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: A Friend.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What wou'd you have?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I'm come for Satisfaction for a Wrong you've done in coming hither to seduce my Mistress from me.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Your Mistress; Who are you?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: A Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Then good Gentleman, go and fetch a Light, and you shall have what you come for presently; tho' the Devil take me, if I'm acquainted with either thee or thy Mistress that I know of.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sir, there needs no Light, the Dark is fitter for my Revenge, therefore guard your self as well as you can, for I have more Swords than my own to assist me.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Ha! Then I fear I'm fallen into the hands of a Villain, not of a Gentleman; but come, I'm bound to try it, come on.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, hold a little, 'Slise if he shou'd make me smart for my fooling, 'twou'd make but an ill Jest;
Pray, Sir, suspend your Fury a while, here will happen no danger, unless you apprehend any from a Woman.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: A Woman!— I thought indeed the Voice did not found very much like a Hero's,— But how shall I know you're a Woman? You've accosted me but odly.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Can't you tell how to find that out?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I don't know faith, I cou'd a done; I'll try.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Pray put up your Weapon first.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Aye, that I will; I think this is too sharp for a Womans use, But why came you in the Dark?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: For fear you shou'd not like me in the Light.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: It must be a very ill Face that can't recommend it self to one Nights Lodging— Prithee let me take a Kiss to sweeten my Imagination however: [Kisses.]— Ha,— A plump smooth Lip, and a Breath sweet as a new pluck't Rose;— Now say thou'rt a Blackamoor if thou wilt, for nothing after this can turn my Stomach.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Where are you pulling me?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Pulling thee, why to Bed.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Hold, not so fast;— I'm come resolv'd to give my self wholly to you, but e're I do so, you must promise me something to deserve it.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: That I will; my Dear, any thing.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But will you perform what you promise?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Don't doubt it; What is it?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: To esteem this Favour, as it is the first I ever granted to any, and in return swear, to love me as long as you live.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Humph— That's a little hard, before I see your Face.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: When I think sit to shew it you, and it prove not a Tolerable one, you shall be dissolv'd from your Oath.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: That's fair, as a Man can desire.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Swear then.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I do; By the dear Pleasure I'm going to possess; upon that Condition, I swear to love thee, and only thee, to the end of my Life.— (Aside)— Whatever we believe of a Woman before Enjoyment, we seldom like 'em so well to think 'em tolerable after it; so there's no great fear of my being forsworn; Come, dear Rogue, come.

sp.speaker: Lady—
sp.p: What a lightness do I wear to seem the thing I am not? Love is too powerful in me to be this Airy thing he takes me for, and before I leave him, I fear I shall betray it, which yet I wou'd not do.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What means this Pause Child? I hope no foolish Qualms to check your Reason.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No, Sir, Only a few Ejaculations before I go to Execution; and now dispose of me as you please.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Then Heaven have mercy upon thy Soul, for I shall have little on thy Body.
sp.stage: [Pulls her, and the Scene shuts upon 'em.
Enter Sir Thomas in a Night-Gown, and Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Are you sure no Body has been here, to speak with my Daughter from Mr. Friendly?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Not that I know of, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: No; nor no Messenger sent from my Daughter to him?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I can't tell, Sir; I did not see any.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Sirrah, stand you here and watch, till towards Morning, and see if you can observe any Body walking about the House, whistling at the Windows, or crying Hist! Ten to one I shall have my Blade a Eves-dropping by and by, or some Body from him; but it shall go hard but I'll spoil their business.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Sir, Sir,— Yonder's some Body with a Light coming down the Field.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Stand still then, and observe.
sp.stage: Enter Hob, with a Candle and Lanthorne.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: So;— This is the House;— Now let me see, how shall I go about to do this same business? if this Old Fox Sir Thomas, shou'd chance to spy me, he'll maul me for certain: But let me alone, I'll be cunning enough for him, I'll warrant me; if he sees me, he must have more Eyes then two— Hold,— hold,— Now let me see for this same Letter;— Oh, here it is;— For Madam Flo — Flo— Madam Flora.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Where are you carrying this Letter Friend?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Letter, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Letter, Sir,— aye Letter, Who did you bring it from?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Bring it from, Sir; I brought it from no Body, not I.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: How came you by it?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: By it, Sir?— Why I found it in my Pocket.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Found it in your Pocket;— What did it grow there?— Ha?— Where are you going with it?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Going with it, Sir; — I don't know where I was going with it, not I.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: What d'ee here at this time of Night?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: I can't tell what I do here, Sir, not I;— I'll go home, Sir, if you please:— God buy t'ee, Sir; — I wish you a good Night:

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Hold,— hold a little, Friend; let me reward you first for bringing of it however.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Not a Farthing, Sir, indeed, I must not take one Farthing; for Mr. Friendly charg'd me to the contrary, therefore pray don't offer it.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: O ho— Did he so? But something I will give you however; pray take that, and that, and that Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: O Lord— O Lord— What d'ee strike me for? What d'ee strike me for? A fore God I'll take the Law of yee, see an I dont; What d'ee go to Murder me?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: I'll Law yee,— you Rogue;— Are you their Letter Carrier? There's more for you, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Bare Witness— bare Witness;— see an you don't pay for this; O Lord! O Lord!

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Sirrah, see him out of my Ground.
sp.stage: Enter Woodvil and Lady as from Bed.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: O Night, thou darling Friend to active Love, keep still thy Mantle spread, and hide us from the World. Beauty needs no light but its own, to see the way to Joy;— Why?— Oh!— Why my Love, will you be gone so soon? The few short hours we've lov'd, has given us but a taste of what we might possess.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Do not ask me more than I'm willing to give; what I have already done, might sure convince you that I had rather stay had I not more weighty Reasons so soon to leave you.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Go not till the Day is broke.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: That you may see my Face;— Go, I shou'd chide your Ungrateful Curiosity; Will you contribute nothing to spare my Blushes? Think what I've done, the Jewel I have parted with; and no security for your faith, but a promise of a moment's growth, what shou'd 'a been dearest to me, like a Toy, I've thrown away; and to compleat me wretched, you may desire my Ruine.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Can it be your Ruine to make my Happiness compleat?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Whilst I'm Conceal'd, shou'd you prove unkind, 'twould rob me but of Life; but if Expos'd; take from me, Life and Reputation.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: You allay my satisfaction, when you doubt my Love, and both that and Honour tie me to secure your Reputation.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: If you have either, I conjure you do not ask it any more; when 'tis fit you shou'd know me better, Love of it self will betray me to you;— for 'twill not be in my power to conceal my self.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Tell me then, when I shall be so blest?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I cannot; but if in the mean time, it will stay your Curiosity to be admitted here another Night, perhaps I may be perswaded to Morrow or next Day to write to you, till then farewell; I know your Lodging.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: O do not stay till the next day, let it be to Morrow, and to Morrow, and every Morrow; let every day be fed with Expectation of the approaching Night, and every Night like this; but with a more lasting Ecstasie.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: How unwillingly my Legs convey me hence; and yet they trembl'd when they brought me here; my Virgin fears hang heavy on my Limbs, and feebl'd all my Joynts! O Love how strange are all thy ways! With dread thou leadst us where we long to be, and when possest of what we come for, with double pain conveys us back again.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Prithee don't rail at him any more; thou hast done enough already to convince me you love him.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I cou'd almost be angry with you for saying so; tho' I know you don't think so.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Indeed I do; and shou'd he Marry Betty to Day, (as I'm sure that's but a pretence to farther some other design, he has in coming here) it would break thy Heart.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You think me very amorous sure to be so smitten with a Man at first sight?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: You can't help it if you are.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But why d'e think I am?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I'll answer you with another Question: Why wou'd you not let me sleep last Night for Talking of him?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Who began it?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I did; because I thought the Discourse wou'd please you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: For what reason?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Because all the Evening you did as you do now, Blush when any Body spoke of him,

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Who can forbear it, to hear you Talk so?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: No Body indeed in thy Condition;— Come prithee Lucia don't vail thy Heart from me; for if thou dost, I'll certainly make thy Case known, and tell Betty what a Rival she has.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I find it is but a folly to say any thing to you; but d'ee really think he can be so in Love with that foolish Girle?— A Man, to all appearance, so much above a Thought so low, methinks 'tis an Injustice to him to believe it, such a Meen and Air in all he says and does, so free and unaffected his Discourse, it creates a Delight in all that hear him.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: His Wit indeed is very engaging.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ay, is it not? And when he addresses— Tho' it is not in a stile so awful as the nicest Vertue wou'd expect; yet it Charms beyond the Oratory of a God.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why do you Laugh?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Only at your not being in [Lucia holds down her Head, hides her Face with her Fan, and runs away. Love, Madam. What a Tyrant is this little Deity? Not satisfy'd with having us poor Virgins in his power, but must shew us in our Fetters; you need not run away from me Lucia, for if thy Malady encrease, the Cordial of a Friends advice will soon fetch thee to me again.
sp.stage: As she is going off, Enter.
Enter Hob, and Country People with a Man Dead-Drunk.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Come Neighbours, bring him along, and set 'en down here, for he must be examin'd, before we part with 'en.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: How now Friends; What Body's that you've got?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Body,— This no Body forsooth; this is a Carcass, one that was a wicked Body.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: What has he done?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Why he has Hang'd himself.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Alas poor Wretch! What was the Cause?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: The Cause;— Why he's Marry'd, and has a Wife and six Children.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Is that a Cause for a Man to Hang himself? What is he?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: What is he? Why he's a Jacobite, and he Hang'd himself, because he would not pay double Taxes.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Pish;—

sp.speaker: Clown,
sp.p: Come Neighbour Hob, you that can tell, pray let us know what we are to do.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Why we that are the Crowner's Quest, the Law says, must enquire how he came by his Death.

sp.speaker: Clown,
sp.p: But of whom must we enquire?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Why, of they that can tell, and no Body knows that so well as himself.

sp.speaker: Clown,
sp.p: Well, but he's Dead.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Why ay, so it seems; and he must be Bury'd if we say he must; and if we say not, it may be not neither.

sp.speaker: Clown,
sp.p: I suppose that's as we shall find him guilty; therefore pray tell me, Neighbour Hob, whether you think a Man that Hangs himself, is guilty of his own Death, or no.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Why truly that's a hard case to judge, Neighbour Clumsey.

sp.speaker: Clown,
sp.p: I think now, that he is guilty.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Hold, hold, take heed, don't be too rash;— for your Conscience must be Umper in this Case:— Look'ee— I put this Point to you now, Whether every one that Hangs himself, is willing to die?

sp.speaker: Clown,
sp.p: I,— I,— Sure he is willing.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Now I say no, for may-hap he might he Non Complementus, and if a Man be Non Complementus, he don't know his own Mind.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: That's true indeed; but now being Dead, pray who must answer the King for the loss of his Subject?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Marry he that Hang'd his Subject: That was himself.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Nay, nay, 'twas the Halter that hang'd him.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Aye, in some sort it did; but that was in se Offendendo, for it may be he went to break the Rope, and the Rope held out in his own defence.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: But is not this same Rope-maker now that made the Rope, in some danger?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
No, no, the Rope-maker can be in no fault;— for d'ee see, when he makes the Rope, he goes backwards, and how can he see before, what shall follow after?— Nor indeed is the Rope in fault, for may be he might urge the Rope Solus Volence, as the Law says,
neither is he himself in fault, for may be his Time was come, and he was born to be Hang'd:— Therefore I do conclude that he was Conscious and guiltless of his own Death.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Why then Neighbour, he may be buried.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: O, of great reason, always he that is alive must die, and he that is dead must be bury'd.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Yet truly I think in my Conscience, he does not deserve to be Bury'd.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: O you speak partiously Neighbour Puzzle-pace,— not deserve to be Bury'd, I say he deserves to be Bury'd alive, that shall Hang himself; therefore don't Take of that.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Well, but what must we do with his Cloaths?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: His Cloaths, why they are the Hangman's.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Why then he must have 'em himself.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Hold, hold,— This is a shrewd point of Law, and must be well handled; Did he make a Will?

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: No, he dy'd detestable.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Why then they fall to the right Heir Male; for look'ee d'ee see, the Female can inherit no Breeches, unless she can prove she wore them in her Husband's Days.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: But suppose he has no Heirs at all?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Why then they go to the chief Mourner,— and look'ee d'ee see, that will be I, I will take his Cloaths; here now I begin with his Cloak,— there now— let every one take a quarter of him, and I'll follow with doleful Lamentation.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Why then, we have done Neighbour, have we?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Ay, ay.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: How dolefully you look Neighbour?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Why, aye; 'tis the fashion so to do; I'm chief Mourner, I must be sad.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Art thou sure he's Drunk?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I'm sure I left him Dead-drunk.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Then I believe they take him for the Man you gave out hang'd himself in Sir Thomas's Orchard to fright the Boys from stealing the Fruit.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: I believe so too, therefore prithee let us make haste for fear they bury him alive.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: 'TIS strange you shou'd not see her Face, but when you tell me you love her, I must laugh at you; what if you have enjoy'd her, 'twas in the dark, and in the same minute your fancy painted her a Venus, you might has suppos'd her a Dowdy, and yet ha' been more just to her.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Aye, but I'm never such an Enemy to my pleasure, to suppose her the last, when I'd more reason to believe her the first; but ●●unck you mistake me, if you think 'tis her I love; no, that's impracticable after Enjoyment; dear Rogue, 'tis the Married Woman I told thee of, that has charm'd my heart; and I have some reason to believe hers is not impenotrable.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Why, d'eo believe it? You durst not sure tell her so?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Why not, her Complexion promis'd me a hearing, and having an opportunity as I was coming away this Morning, thro' the Garden where she was walking, I spoke to her, and told her, the seign'd Love I own'd last Night for her Servant, was a Plot I had brib'd her Maid to assist me in, to get an opportunity to confess the real one I had for her.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Very good;— and no doubt but she beliv'd you.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: She seem'd at first a little surpriz'd, but before I left her, I prevail'd so for, to gain a promise to see her again; and how much that may conduce to a good conclusion, you may imagine.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: How do you know, but this may be the same Woman you lay with last Night.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Prithee don't call my Judgment in question; canst thou believe me so raw a Gamester not to know a Maid from a Married Woman.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I know not what you may do; but I'm sure 'tis a Secret I'm yet to learn; but come you must go along with me, Flora has sent me word to day will be kept a Wake before their house, and if in the Crowd she can get loose from her Father, we may chance make work for the Parson.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I'm sorry for't, I had rather help you to make work for the Midwife, I don't care to meddle where the Church is concern'd.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Is not that he, see.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: It is Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Follow him, and give him this.

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: To what end, Madam; you have found him false already.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Dispute not my Commands, but fly. [Ex. Betty. He has undone me, if he leaves me not, which I too justly fear; for he has already discover'd the Inconstancy of his Sex, and what he promis'dd me unknown at Night, in the Morning broke to me, when he took me for another.
How now! Did you give it him?

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: I did, Madam; and he'll see you he says.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Do'st not think he suspects me to he her that was with him last Night?

sp.speaker: Bet.
sp.p: No, Madam; but believing me to be confident to both her and you, he has brib'd me to keep you ignorant of each others Loves, and assist him in your several Intrigues.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Perjur'd base Villain! Why am I fated to Love, and not the Infection on my Lips, that when his flattery wou'd feal my ruine, he there might meet his own.

div.head: SCENE II. A Fair.
div.stage: Enter Old Hob and his Wife, with Benches to set at the Door and Forms.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Come, Husband, good now make haste; the Town will be full of People, before we shall get fitted.

sp.speaker: O. Hob.
sp.p: Don't trouble thy self Wife, every thing within Doors is ready; and there is nothing wanting without but the Sign to be put up, and look'ee, that shall be done present; Hob— Hob—

sp.speaker: Hob within.
sp.p: What say you Father?

sp.speaker: O. Hob.
sp.p: Go and Tap th'ale, quick, quick.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Aye, aye Father.

sp.speaker: O. Hob.
sp.p: There— Now he that will drink good Ale, let e'n come to th'Sign oth'Potlid. Come, Wife, let's to our business within.
sp.stage: Enter Friendly and Woodvill: Sir Thomas, Flora, and Lucia at the Balcony.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: If these Disguises will let us stand unsuspected, we may be able to attempt something to gain my Flora's freedom.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Ay, and lose thy own.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Yonder she is with her pretty friend; and old Argus that sticks to 'em, like Murder to a troubl'd Conscience.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Ha! Are these the Jewels of such vertue? One of them I'm sure has none to boast of; nor will the other, I believe, be a Martyr for her Honour.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Now Ned, tell me, How do'st like my Mistress?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Like her?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Ay, like her?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Very well for a Mistress.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: A Mistress!

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Ay, why dost think I can like her for any thing else?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I do, Sir, and think my self happy in my Choice.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I'm glad you'r so pleas'd, Sir, I can have her at a clieaper rate.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Ha! What dice mean?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Not to hear any thing dishonourably spoken of her I Love, tho' by my Friend.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Hum— (Aside)— Nor ought I indeed in honour, if it was she that did me the favour last night, tho' it be to my Friend; Come, prithee smooth thy Brow, Franck, thou knowest I have but a loose Opinion of all Women, which but seldom will let me speak well of any, tho' they deserve it.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Good Manners shou'd correct that ill Custom in a Gentleman, and for your own sake, pray be perswaded to forget it.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Grave Sir, I shall Edifie— (Aside)— in the knowledge of my Mistress, I hope, the next time I have her at Blindman's-Buff, or she shall keep my Head in the Bag!

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Come Gentlewomen, if you must see the Pastime, you may have as fair a Prospect of 'em here, as you can in the Crowd, and with less danger to your Reputations.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: Our Reputations! In what can they suffer, amongst such people as resort here?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Why these are Men, and fitter for Womens use than Finical Fops, that have only the appearance of Men; meer outsides, the signs of Men; and such I have known a Woman fond of.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: 'Tis very hard Sir, we can't be where we like best, I think we are at Age to look after our selves.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Aye, if you had but Grace to take care of your selves too.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Women at our years, know how to make their choice; or if we did not we are seldom instructed by ill usage.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Eh— eh— What,— what are you a chattering Magpye, hee— do you want to have your Leggs at liberty?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: If I do, I can have patience; for I shan't want it long, unless you cou'd confine my inclinations too.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Let me come at her,— let me come at her,— what does she prate again to me? You are one to be intrusted with your self indeed, look'e here else, witness this Letter, I got scouting from your Lover to ye; de'e see here I can't read it now for want of my Spectacles, but here he says how that she has given him a new life, from the last favour she was pleas'd to grant him;— Hark'ee Hussey, what favour was that you were so pleas'd to grant him, tell me, for I will know what that favour was?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I don't know what you mean Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p:
What, not by the last favour?— Afore God i'll have her search't;— I'll know how far the honour of my Family was concern'd in that last favour of hers;— I will Gentlewomen.— And sure I shall find an Expedient too, to keep you asunder, if Locks,
