and Bolts, and Barrs can do it:— Odso well remember'd, let me see if my Doors are all fast, and then if you can shufle Love through the Key-hole, withall my heart.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: Prithee see Flor, if I'm not mistaken, on of those men yonder looks like your lover Friendly in disguise.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: And the other the very sperk that lay here last night, I now begin to think Friendly employ'd him about that piece of Knight Errantry; to get news from our enchanted Castle, or to try if thou hadst Chrams enough to engage him to yoke with his friend.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: Why d'ee think so?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Because there are few men that marry in this Age; but are asham'd of their fortune; and wou'd therefore draw in as many of their freinds as they can to Countenance their folly as they call it.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: I have a better opinion of your Lover, Flora.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: He's oblig'd to ye Madam.
sp.stage: Enter Hob with a blue Apron on.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Ch'm coming, Ch'm coming; your Servant Mr. Friendly, I'm glad to see you; you'r welcome to'th Fair.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I thank the Honest Hob.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: I shou'd know that Gentleman,— Master Woodvill I think.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Aye Hob, how dost do?

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: O Lord Master, how de'e do? Faith I'm glad to see you with all my heart; Lord a mercy upon us; how strangly you be grown since you have been over-Seas;— Come, pray sit you down— Master Freindly,— Come pray stay, and drink one Pott afore you go.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Prithee let us sit down, or this fellows impertinence will make us observ'd.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What do'st thou do with an Apron Hob?

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: A Dod, I put un on but just now; Father will do as Meighbours do, and every one it'h Town a most sells Ale on Fair day, but now we sell several other sorts of liquor; and Wine too an occasion be.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Wine?

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Aye, all sorts of Wine.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Sayest a so, bring us some Claret then.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Claret Sir, we've no Claret, we must not sell Claret; 'tis against the Law, now you may have some of your Port, your red Port now, or your white Port, or such sort of Stuff.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Such stuff as thou hast then, Prithee bring us.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Yes Sir,— (is going and then turns back.)— Now in my mind Sir,— what d'ee think of a little Sack, a little Sack now, and some of your Sugar in't, is main good.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Pirthee bring, what thou lik'st best thy self— For I'm sure 'twill please no palate but thy own.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I fear Frank, your project will not answer your end, for I see no way of getting at the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: There is but little hopes indeed Ned, since I see the doors shut, and the old Knight in their Company; fortune may do something unexpectedly to befriend us.
sp.stage: Enter Hob with two Black Potts, a Trencher with Tobacca, Pipes, and Bread and Cheese upon it.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Ch'm coming, ch'm coming, here Sir.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Where is the Sack?

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Sack Sir,— Od I don't know, I thought you said you had rather have Ale— Ale is indeed much wholsomer now, for your English Stomaches;— for my Part, i'd rather have Ale now; Master Woodvill, bite a bit afore you drink:— Come and mean time i'll put a little Sugar i'th Ale; and make it as good as I can for you:— Come Sir, against your dispose'd—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Thank ye Hob, this fellows kindness will poyson me before I go hence.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Not whilst you have such a Taster; for I don't see that he intends to leave you any.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: A Dod 'tis main good Sir;— will you have tother Pott Sir?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: No, prithee drink this too, and then fetch us a Couple.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Yes Sir,— I will, I will.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: above, Come my merry Countrymen, every man take his Lass, and give us a Dance or two, and then wee'll have the Cudgells, out.
sp.stage: Enter Hob with the Potts of Ale, stares on the Dancers and Dance— minds not the Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Yes, an't like your Worships, we are all ready, come Scratch strike up. — Dance.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Aye marry Sir, well done Ralph; set to u'n Joane, set toe'n.

sp.speaker: Hob's
sp.p: Mother within. Hob, Hob.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Ch'm coming, ch'm coming (he Sings) Toll, ●●ll, in Mary, Sides all now, sides all.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Hob, Hob.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Ch'm coming, ch'm coming Master, toll, loll, &c.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p:
Ch'm coming, ch'm coming, what a Plague ails my Father trow? and old Fool! Udsbled he makes more a noise,— set to now, William, ah rarely done; in Mary, O dainty Mary, turn her about now John, now, now, a murrain, you're quite out: Hold, hold, ye are all out, look Ralph shou'd a cast off, and while John had turn'd Mary about, Thomas shou'd a led up Nan, and Joan met Ralph at Bottom again, mean while John shou'd a sided with Mary; and then Mary shou'd
back to back with Ralph, and then Thomas had come in again in his own place, and so all had been right.— Come begin again, strike up scratch, Toll, loll, doll, loll, &c.

sp.speaker: O. Hob within,
sp.p: Hob, Hob, Where be ye?

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Ch'm coming, ch'm coming, what the Devil can't you be quiet a bit, toll, loll, &c.

sp.speaker: O. Hob,
sp.p: Hey day, hey day, this is rare sport, I God, i'll strap you, ye base Rogue you; must you be danceing here, and your Mother and I at work.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Hey day! what's the matter now? what, must I be beat all the days of my life?

sp.speaker: O. Hob,
sp.p: Ye Graceless Rogue, mind your business then, do ye, yonders your poor Mother within a scoreing and a scoring till she sweats again, and no body to draw one drop of Beer:

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: I don't care a farthing, I won't draw a drop more if you go to that, do your worst, and take your Course.

sp.speaker: O. Hob,
sp.p: Sirrah, come ye in, and don't ye stand dancing here, don't ye.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: I won't go in, so I won't, if that trouble yo, I will Dance, and Dance again — Angerly, toll, loll, &c.

sp.speaker: O. Hob,
sp.p: Aye thou'rt an untoward Boy as e're was born; Mercy forgive me for begetting the.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Marry come up, what's here to do I trow?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Here's the Cudgells an't like you, will your Worship please to have us begin.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Aye, Aye, by all means make hast Roger, and bring forth the Hatt and the Favour.

sp.speaker: Roger,
sp.p: Here it is, an't please ye.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p:
Hang it up there, and he that wiens it, let him wear it. The first Sommersetshireman that breaks a Head, here's half a Crown for him to drink; and
he that breaks that Rogue Hobs head, shall have another.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Shall he— look'e, he that breaks my Head, shall have somewhat to do, i'll tell you that, let 'en be who he will, he shall earn his Money, Ecod ill rib' en— And look'e, to begin here i'll take up the Cudgell,— And now let the best man here, take up tother, an he dare, if he be a Sommersetshireman, let 'en be a Sommersetshireman,— I sight for Glostershire; I don't care who knows it.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: At him, at him there— What, is there no body dare venture upon him? Neighbour Puzlepate, take up the to ' ther Cudgell.

sp.speaker: Puzzle,
sp.p: Not I an 't please you, I have enough of 'en already, he broke my Head but last week.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Roger,— Sirrah, do you take up the Cudgell, and thrash him, do'e hear— thrash him soundly Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Roger,
sp.p: I can't promise that Sir, I'll do my best, I'll break his head if I can in Love; and if he breaks mine, much good may do him.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: This is as I cou'd wish; If Hob does but get the better of the Combat, the Testy Knight will certainly be provok'd to come down, and then we shall have sport.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Prithee let's encourage him then; O brave Hob, now for Glostershire Hob.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: I warrant ye Master, let me alone.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Here Hob, there's an Angel for thee.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: And break his head Hob; and I'll give the another.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Don'te fear Master, I God I'll noint 'en.

sp.speaker: Rogger,
sp.p: Do if thou canst; I don't fear thee Hob.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: S'bleed, I'll dress thy Jacket; I'll dowse thy Somersetshire Coate for thee.

sp.speaker: Roger,
sp.p: Come on then.

sp.speaker: Clown,
sp.p: Obrave Hob.

sp.speaker: Clown,
sp.p: Obrave Roger.

sp.speaker: Clown,
sp.p: Obrave Hob.
sp.stage: Here they play and Hob breaks to'thers Head.

sp.speaker: Clown,
sp.p: Obrave Roger.
All the Clowns Hollow!

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: I God I've don't; I've don't Faith.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Foul, foul, foul.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Fair, fair, fair.

sp.speaker: Clown.
sp.p: Here take the Hat Hob.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: You lye, you Doggs, 'twas foul.
All Clowns Hollow!

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Stand upon thy Guard Hob, the Kinght's coming down to thee.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Is a, let 'en come and welcome; here I'll stand, I'll take no other than St. George's Guard; if he let's drive at me, Fore-god I'll hit 'en over the Sconce, if he was a Knight of Gold.
sp.stage: Enter Sir Thomas from the Balcony.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Where are these Bumpkins?— Now who dars say 'tis fair.
I say 'tis foul.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: I say 'tis fair.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: So is that too Sir Thomas and Hob fights; Hob breaks the Knights Head; the Clowns hollow and cry fair; then the Knight draws his Sword and beats Hob and the Clowns off.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: O brave Knight!
He has bestirr'd himself I saith, with as much courage, as if he fought for distressed Damsels.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: So he has I thank him: Here's liberty for you Madam unexpected, if you'll embrace it come down quickly.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Your Jaylor's gone Ladies, and the doors open, come down and we'ell knock off your Fetters.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: To put on stronger of your own

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Not I faith, I'd have every Woman use her leggs as she pleases.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: So shalt thou thy tongue hereafter; But prithee let me Confine it now, for we have no time to talk.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: What is it, you wou'd have of me Friendly?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Remember your promise Madam; and spare that question.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I don't know what his design is Madam; but here's a Parson planted hard by I can till you, I believe a purpose to do mischief.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I own my promise to marry you, but do not remember I ever oblig'd my self to time.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Be it still unlimited, I'll never press it against your will: All I ask now is, to deliver your self from Bondage.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: What sayst thou Lucia, shall I go?

sp.speaker: Luoi.
sp.p: If I thought you'd take my advice, I'd give it you, but I'm sure you'll adhere to none but that of running away, therefore prithee make haste and begone.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Farewell then.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: But hast thou the Conscience to leave me behind, to be punished for thy sins?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Aye, if you can have the heart to let me go without ye.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Make haste Madam, your Fathers returning.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: We come, we come, fly good Lucia.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: 'Tis pity that Marriage shou'd be the end of this Adventure, it looks so like Whoring; I wish the old Fellows Wife had been in their company, to a got me a Stomach to the Business.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Upon my Knees I shou'd receive you Madam; but the place—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Will not let us lose time in talking— where's my Cousin? Where's my Cousin?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Leave her to my Friends charge— He's an honest Gentleman, and will take care of her.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: A Pox of your honest Commendations, let me speak for my self, Madam, here's your Man.

sp.speaker: Luci.
sp.p: What to do? Not to follow our Friends example I hope.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: No faith Child, I'm better principl'd; thou shalt have me upon easier Terms.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: There— there you Rustich Rogues,— you hard headed Doggs, I think I've at last met with your Sculls; I believe I have notch't some of your Noddles for you; I have made you pay for shedding my Blood.
sp.stage: Enter a Maid and Roger, and Servant.

sp.speaker: Maid,
sp.p: Oh Sir, Sir, We're undone, Madam Flora and Madam Lucia.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: What of them?

sp.speaker: Maid,
sp.p: They are gone Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Gone where?

sp.speaker: Roger
sp.p: With a Couple of Gentlemen Sir, No body knows where.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: The Devil go with 'em— which way are they gone?

sp.speaker: Servant,
sp.p: They have taken towards the Road Sir, but they can't be got far.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Bid every one of your fellows take Horse immediately, and ride several ways;— Have they slipt through my fingers at last.— Make haste you Doggs— (beats 'em) make haste fly, fly.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p:
If reason had a power in Love, I shou'd not fann this fire within me, to make a Ruin of my Peace,— But oh I strive in vain, my ungoverned passion
drives me on, though sure Destruction follows me: What is't a Clock?

sp.speaker: Betty,
sp.p: Four Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Look if you can see him coming.

sp.speaker: Betty,
sp.p: He's just here Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: O cou'd he bring a heart like that hee'l find here; how happy would this meeting be?— But that's impossible.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: So much for my honest obligation; we have hous'd they Lads; my friends business is done:— Now let me look after my own—; 'tis something past the time,— ha!

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: You see Sir, how much you have prevail'd upon me, am I not punctual?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Pardon me Madam, if I seem not so, in suffering you here before me; a fault nothing but a businss of no less concern than Life and Death, should a made me guilty of.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: So, there's one lye already.— (aside)— What business? The carrying away Sir Thomas's Neice and Daughter.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: How the Devil came she to know that?

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Come, since I know you were ingaged in that piece of Chivalry, you may spare the expence of an invenion to hide it.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: 'Tis true Madam; I did give some little assistance in that affair to the service of my friend, but—

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: But the extent of your desire is only to engage my heart i'll warrant.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: 'Tis the last of all my wishes, from the first moment I saw you at Church—

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: At Church?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Aye, at Church Madam;— pray Heav'n she goes to Church (aside). 'Twas there I first beheld you; and there promised never to think of any other Women.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: My pretended flekness has kept me from Church, ever since I've been here; but I believe if he cou'd have thought I had been to be found at Rome, he had said he had seen me there;— Well Sir, I will not question the truth of what you say: But if I shou'd be inclinable to believe you, what wou'd you do to deserve it?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: All things that's possible my Unartful Passion will Compell me to.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: All things but Constancy; and that I fear is not in your Passion.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: It is the only sin of my Affection, if it be one to love forever.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: O Heaven! that truth dwelt in his words. (aside)— Swear— Swear that thou lovest me.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I do by all—

sp.speaker: ady
sp.p: Hold,— hold— I know there's nothing but he will Swear: And break it when he has done; and yet he must swear it;— for there is such a Charm in the Cheat; that again I must hear him, and be again deceiv'd.

sp.speaker: Betty,
sp.p: How then, I must leave you, when next I see you.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: You'll perhaps again be taken from me; let me not part with you now.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: I must be gone.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Then take me with you.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: What to do?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: That wee'll talk of by and by.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: But the time will be so short.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: That we shall have no time to talk;— Well hinted I Gad— [Aside, On then my Dear, that we may not lose that little we have.
sp.stage: Enter Sir Thomas with Constable and Watch.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: A Pox upon you, for a company of uncultivated Clods; where de'e hall me?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Sir, what we do we are bound to; 'tis our Office, therefore pray forgive us

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: You are not going to Execution with me, you ask pardon so like a Hangman;

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: No Sir, Our Warrant is only to carry you before a Justice, and from thence I believe to Prison: but where afterwards I dare not say; but I am afraid your Worships time is but short.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Not so short as you'd make it, you dund-headed Doggs, to be tryed, Condemn'd and Hang'd in a Breath.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: No Sir, I hope not; Tho your Worship made but quick work with poor Hob.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: Aye, aye poor man; his head has done aking by this time:

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: I'm glad of it; and had I my Sword, and my hands at liberty none of your shou'd trouble you long.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: O bloody, bloody, away with him; this is bloody Neighbours.
All, Away, away with him.
sp.stage: Enter Friendly and Robin, meeting Probe the Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: So Mr. Probe, how de'e find your Patient?

sp.speaker: Probe,
sp.p: Alas his Wound is nothing; his Scull is not so much as touch't tho he fancies it impossible for a cut with a Sword to be less than Mortal.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Poor Hob, you must still keep him ignorant of his Condition, and make him believe it's dangerous; it may be of use to me:

sp.speaker: Probe,
sp.p: I need not do that, his fears won't let him believe otherwise; let me say what I can.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Robin, come let us go see if we can find Mr. Woodvill, for without his help we shall hardly bring our Plot to perfection.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Not Jove in all his transformations, when he Ungodded himself for Mortal Pleasures, had one hour of Love like me. O for a Night to Revel in; that the Taste might be turn'd into a Feast; And my longing Soul be fill'd with delight.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Is not this Extasie feigned: And shall not the easie access you have found to my heart, make me one day slighted for another.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Wrong not thy self with such a thought,— there can be no other but thee: Thou Charmer tell me when shall I see thee again?

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: I cannot tell, this Evening i'll endeavour it; and if 'tis possible I will meet you here;— tell then— Farewell.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Farewell my Dear, Dear Creature.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Have you my things Betty?

sp.speaker: Betty,
sp.p: Here they be Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Give 'em to me; i'll put 'em on as I go; if he takes not the nearest way I may meet him at the lower end of the Walk.
sp.stage: Re-enter Woodvill, meeting Friendly and Robin.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: O well met; I find I might have look't long enough for you, had not chance brought me to a sight of you:— Come Robin the things, quick, quick.

sp.speaker: Robin,
sp.p: Here Sir, here.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: How now, what are these for?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Nay, prithee ask no questions; But if you'll do me a piece of service, come on with this Holy outside, you must suffer a Transformation Ned; from a Town Bull to Parish-Priest.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: That's the same thing still Frank; But to what end must I wear this Mantle, for Iniquity?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Can't you guess?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Not I faith, unless it be to mock Matrimony; And if that's the business come on, as fast as you will, I'm for you.

sp.speaker: Frend.
sp.p: How! I did not think thou hadst been so well acquainted with Religion, to be able to act any thing of it.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Yes, yes, to serve a friend upon occasion Franck; I have study'd it a little.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: And a very little, nor that for any affection thou hadst to it, i'll be sworn, Come, come along.
sp.stage: As Woodvill follows, Enter Lady Teste at the other side Mask'd— And pulls him back.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: A word with you Sir,— If the care of some departing Soul does not make you too much in haste.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Thou dear Creature, have I met thee here again? And art thou come to perform they last promise; and let me see that beautious Face of thine?

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Why shou'd you be so curious? for if it prove handsome you know the engagement you lye under.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What, to love thee?— 'Tis impossible my dear for me ever to love any body else.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: So,— What de'e do with this habit then?— I fear there is something to be manag'd in this disguise, not of a piece with your vows.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: This habit Child; why I procur'd it a purpose to try if by it's assistance I cou'd find some way to get access to thee.

sp.speaker: Lady,
sp.p: Thou lyest thou Devil; and the Curse of broken promises pursue thee for it.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Hey day! what's the meaning of this Divinity, if you bring me no better fortune, you must go home and Cloak for the good Wives of your own Parish again.
sp.l: To Levies Tribe they'l part with any thing.

l.hi: And thank the Saint that takes the Offering.

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth Act.

div.head: ACT. V.
SCENE. I.
div.stage: Hob is brought in a Chair by some Country Fellows, his Father and Mother with him.

sp.speaker: Old Hob,
sp.p: COme easie Neighbours, easie, set 'en down easie.

sp.speaker: Mother,
sp.p: O my poor Child, how dost thou do?

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Worser and worser, I find I'm not for this Life.

sp.speaker: Old Hob,
sp.p: Then I hope you'll take warning, how oft have I said. Hob says I don't thee concern thy self; what business is it of thine? Let every Tub stand upon its own bottom; but thou thought'st because—

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Pray now don't ye talk to me, pray now don't; Don't ye vex me so: 'Tis a strange thing you can't let me depart in peace.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: How de'e Neighbour? how does your Son?

sp.speaker: O. Hob.
sp.p: Ah Sir, the poor boy I'm afraid will dye.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Who is that Neighbour?

sp.speaker: Clown,
sp.p: It is the Parson come to Pray with thee Hob.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Ha! What do'st say, the Parson?— O Lord, I hope it is not come to that is it?— O my heart, O my poor heart will break; O— O Lord.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: Come Patience, Patience Neighbour, have a little Patience— And I hope as you have liv'd a good Christian, you'll take care to dye so.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Aye sure Sir, that I will, under Mercy; for if I live I will dye a good Protestant.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: That's well said, then the first thing you must do, is to forget and forgive.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Forgive?— What must I forgive him that has knock't out my brains? Why then may hap he'll do so again.

sp.speaker: Pars.
sp.p: If he does, you must forgive him.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Aye,— why then if I must, I do forgive him.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Hob, Child here's Mary come to see thee.

sp.speaker: Mary,
sp.p: How dost find thy self Hob.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Ah Mary, I can't speak to thee.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Poor heart;— do try to speak to her child, for she is thy Wife and no other.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: I know I'm sure to her,— and I do own it before you all, I ask't her the Question, last Lammas; and at Allhollows-tide we broke a piece of Money; and if I had liv'd till last Sunday, we had been ask'd in the Church.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Ha poor wretch I always thought 'en to pretty to live — Mary, go and kiss 'en Mary.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.q: I do desire you all present, to take notice of my last Will and Testimony.— I have forty Shillings in a leatherpurse under my Beds-head, which I do bequeath unto Mary; And the ball'd-fac'd Heifer that I bought at Tukesbury-Fair, I do bequeath unto Mary;— And my new leather Breeches, which I bought against Whitsontide: I do bequeath unto Mary; And my Bible, and new Pitchfork, and Tobacco-box, I do bequeath unto Mary: Mary, come and kiss me once more, Mary you may never kiss me again.

sp.speaker: Probe,
sp.p: How now, what's the matter;— how dost do Friend?

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Dead Sir,— I'm a Dead Man.

sp.speaker: Probe,
sp.p: How Dead! Thou art the first Dead Man that ever told me so; let me feel thy Pulse.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: O Sir, they do beat, beat, like any Durm.

sp.speaker: Probe,
sp.p: O your Pulse beats very temperate.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Do they Sir?

sp.speaker: Probe,
sp.p: Aye, aye, you're better than you was a great deal.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Am I indeed Sir?

sp.speaker: Probe,
sp.p: What have you given him to eat?

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Nothing Sir, I have eat no kind of thing: Sir Thomas sent a Doctor here, and I believe he had a mind tof amish me, he gave me a sort of stuffe here made of Barly;— Barly Porridge I think they call it; 'twas no sooner in but out again; it runs through a man and does no manner of good.

sp.speaker: Probe,
sp.p: You must have some thing to strengthen him; what have you a mind to?

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: I don't know Sir; I cou'd eat something fit for a man in my Condition;— a little somewhat Roast;— what de'e think of a little Roast-beef now;— and a little Pepper and Vinigar to make it Savory, may hap I cou'd get a bit of that down.

sp.speaker: Probe,
sp.p: O a very good thing for a sick man; let him have it, and give him some Sack now and then; there's half a Dozen Bottles within, which Mr. Friendly sent to comfort him with.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Has a,— God bless 'en—. Ha! he's a good man— Mother give me a little Sack, will ye pray now do.

sp.speaker: Probe,
sp.p: Well, how de'e find your self now?

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Ha,— ha— add I don't know Sir,— methinks I'm pretty hoddy now as 'twere.

sp.speaker: Probe,
sp.p: That's well, why then let him drink another Cup.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Shall I?— Why so, I will then— Mother give me a sup or two more— Hee— hee— hee.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Ah much good do thy precious heart; how dost do now Child.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Ha— add I'm fine and spract now.

sp.speaker: Probe,
sp.p: Pough,— you'll do very well again; I'd have you try to get up, and i'll come and see you again anon.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Thank you Sir, heartily;— Sir, Sir, pray take the Parson a long with you, I don't care to see 'en here, a looks unlucky methinks.

sp.speaker: Probe,
sp.p: Aye, aye, I will.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Mother I'll try if I can walk a bit.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Do then stand up.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Pray lend me my Breeches Father.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: O don't be too bold good Hob.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Give me a little more Sack [Drink]— It's good Sack Mother, pray lend me the— O Lord.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Get on thy Cloths first, good Child.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: I'm, I'm, very fainty,— I wont venture too soon Mother.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Don't then, sit down, and let them carr thee in again.

sp.speaker: Hob,
sp.p: Aye, so I will.

sp.speaker: O. Hob,
sp.p: Come help Neighbours.

sp.speaker: Sir, Tho.
sp.p: I have misfortunes enough to send me into the other world, without a Halter; I need not swing thither for a Rogue not worth the Money the Rope will cost;— but if I be hang'd, it shall be a day of mourning for some-body.
sp.stage: Enter Wood vill habited like a Parson.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Save you Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: And you too Sir, have you any thing to say to me?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Yes Sir, I hear you are to be try'd for Murder, and as the Fact appears to me, you will suffer for it.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Well, and what then?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I wou'd know in what state, you are in, and if you are prepar'd for Death as you ought to be.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: You know;— What with that Face,— prithee get some hair on thy Chin first— boy— thy outside will beget no veneration in me.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: My inside won't I'm sure— [Aside]— Sir, I expected another sort of treatment from a man in your Condition.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Why, what's my Condition Cobble Conscience?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Do ye know where you are a going?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: No nor you neither Sir, for all you get your living by it.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: This way Sir, won't convey you to Heaven.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Why then I'll go to to'ther place along with you.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: And is this all the Preparation you intend to make for your Journey.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Aye Sir, I shall go just as I am, without Boots or Spurs; you may therefore spare your pains, if you please.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What an old Reprobat have I to work upon.
sp.stage: Enters Saywell and Friendly. drest like a Lawyer.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.p: Your Servant Sir, I'am glad to see you in such good Company.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: 'Tis the Company Neighbour Saywell, that will bring me to the Gallows;— The Parson and the Hangman are the two last that take leave of us there. Have you brought my Writings.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.p: I have Sir, and here's a Gentleman recommended to me for an able Lawyer, that will settle your Estate as you shall think fit.

sp.speaker: Jay.
sp.p: Sir, here's a young Lady without, desires to see you.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: O 'tis my Wife, let her come to me.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I'm afraid the help I can give you, will do but little service, for he's as much averse to a black Gown, as a Non-Con is to a Surplice: What have you done with the Ladies?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: They're safe at my Aunt Friendlies.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Do's Flora know of your Plott.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: No, nor of her Fathers being here; nor durst I tell her, till I have effected my design; for tho it is only for her sake, if I do get her Fortune, yet t'wou'd displease her if she knew I but attempted it.— Ha!

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: O, shew me, shew me, where on my knees I may fix, till my Tears have wash'd away my Offences; O Sir, forgive my Disobedience, that has I fear been too much the cause of this most fatal accident.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Hum,— get out of my sight,— get out of my sight— Go get you gone to your Rogue, that will have mehang'd, go and I'll provide for ye;— I'll give you a Portion, Twelve-pence and thy Fathers Curse, be thine Inheritance.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What a Pox is the meaning of all this?

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: O do not Curse me Sir, I have not deserv'd that, leave me a Beggar if you please, but with your Blessing and I will be contented.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: What, bless thee for contriving to have me hang'd? be gone.— begone from me quickly, or I will fist thee from me.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Do any thing Sir, so you will heat me;— Let me clear my Innocence, and banish me your sight forever turning to Wood. O Sir, I beseech you plead for me, it is your Duty to Reconcile us, and yours, and yours turning [to Mr. Saywell and Friendly]: And every good mans, to help the distress'd.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I'm so amaz'd I cannot think what to do, if I discover my self to her in this humour, she'll not have patience to let me undeceive her.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: So, I find our Plot is growing to an end already; How like two Fools we shall look by and by, if they find us out in our borrowed shapes.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.p: Come, pray let me persuade you to hear her however, you are never the farther from your Resolution.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: What can she say for her self, am I not brought here for Murder, provok't to it by their invention, she and her Rogue Friendly, that she ran away with; did you not run away with him Huzzey.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I did Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Very good; Come, I'll reason the matter calmly with you; and have you not married him too, against my express Command to the Contrary.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: No, Sir nor never will.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Swear, swear that, and damn thy self.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: By all my hopes of future Blessings, he is not my Husband; nor till within this half hour, did I know of your imprisonment, or the fatal cause.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: If this be true.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: If it be not let misery persue me.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Will you promise me not to marry him when I'm dead, for hang me I suppose they will.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: O do not name him, Death wou'd be a thousand times more wellcome to me, than such a Husband.

sp.speaker: Friend,
sp.p: So now I may go hang my self.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Well, on condition that all you have said is true, I do forgive thee, rise up and Heaven bless thee.

sp.speaker: Friendly,
sp.p: Dear Ned, what shall I do.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Why, as thou saidst just now, hang thy self; for since thou canst not marry to cure thy passion, I know no other way.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.p: You will do well, Sir Thomas, for she has exprest her self a very dutiful Child.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: She has so, and I will reward her for it, here is a Deed of Gift of half my Estate, which I did once before design for her, but happening to fall in Love at that Juncture, and marrying I alter'd my Resolution, here Sir,—

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.p: Mr. Nonsuit;

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Come and witness this, the rest of my Estate I will settle upon my Wife, and let the Writings be drawn as soon as you can.

sp.speaker: Friendly,
sp.p: Sir, they shall be ordered immediately.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Sir, your hand too.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Withall my heart; and heaven give a blessing to't:

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: There I deliver this as my Act and Deed.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: So, I'm glad however I've seen this done for her! tho she has renounc't me for ever.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: I wish I cou'd have liv'd to a seen thee married; my death had been more supportable to me.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I wish so to Sir, for I'm young and know not how the subtilties of men may prevail, when you are gone that shou'd advise me: But for fear this Friendly shou'd attempt me again, to make me break the promise I have made you; I will this minute put it out of my power, and give my self to this Gentleman Mr. Nonsuit, if he'll please to accept of me.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Ha, accept of thee.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Nay,— you don't deserve me, for not letting me know your designs upon my Father, am I not fit to be trusted with my own welfare think ye.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Oons!

sp.speaker: Friend
sp.p: Forgive me Madam, and had I—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Nay, no Apology, I'm satisfi'd that I'm not oblidg'd to your Plot for what I have, but my own.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: By all that's sacred I will deserve thee, if it be in Love to reward this unexpected blessing, tell me you Powers, if there be any that knows a happiness like mine; how shall I express my Joy.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Woons, what is all this?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: O good Sir, forbear swearing; 'tis an hollow'd sound, and my ears can't bear it.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Rot you and your ears, you Canonical Pimp, Confussion I'm cheated out of my Estate too, as well as my life.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: No Sir I will take care your Estate shall be dispos'd of according to your Act and Deed; and you may live to now if you please, and enjoy your liberty.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: Which you had never wanted (Pardon me Sir) had you given me mine.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Patience give me Patience.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.p: In troth, Neighbour,— 'tis the best Remedy you can have; e'en make use of it, and let that seem your choice which is not now in your power to help.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: What wou'd you have me do? Wou'd you have me give her to him?

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.p: Aye, and your Blessing too, or they'll be happy without it; an Estate is a good step to it, and that you have given 'em already; and there few Children in this Age, that think their Parents can add any thing more.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Come hither,— Take her, and make her—

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Any thing but a Wife, or I forbid [Woodvile interposes. the Banes.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: You forbid the Banes.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: What's the meaning of this?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Look'ee Frank, while the Jest wou'd bare, I was willing to carry it on;— But the Business grows now too much in earnest; and the Welfare of my Friend obliges me to make bold with my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: What say ye, your Mistress?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Aye your Lady, and her Companion, were the two Masks that I told you I pick't up, and one of 'em, I thank her, did me the Favour to afford me her Company that Night, if it was Flora she has something very particular in her behaviour that makes her a very agreeable Bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Thou durst not sure say this to me in earnest?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: But I dare, Sir, if it be truth, as I'm sure it is; tho', perhaps, you mayn't care to hear it.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: By Heav'n thou ly'st, and did not her presence make this place sacred, thou shoud'st pay dear for this Blasphemy.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Are you so hot? Follow me, and I'll find you a place to allay your fury in.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Follow thee—

sp.speaker: Flor.
sp.p: Hold, you shall not go; What's the meaning of this?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What's the matter? — [As Wood. is going out,
sp.stage: Enter Lady Testie in a Mask, meeting him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: With your leave, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What are you surpriz'd to see me here?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Ay, I'gad, am I, more than ever I was in my Life.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sir, 'tis hard to conceal wrongs, from a Jealous Mistress.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: And 'tis harder for me to do you right, whilst you conceal your self.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why did you not meet me, as you promis'd?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Meet you; S'bud I thought I had you here; but since I find I'm mastaken, pray, Madam, satisfie me, who you are? For if you remember, when you and I Bargain'd for a little Familiarity, I was to be under no obligation, till I had seen and lik'd you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: That you have done already, if you spoke truth; but since you are so apt to forget, refresh your Memory and look again; What are you Dumb? [Pulls off her Mask.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I shou'd be dumb, Madam, if—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: If thou hadst nothing to say, but thou hast a Tongue can never want words to excuse thy Perjury, shou'd I stay to hear it; farewel, ungrateful Man.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: So, very well, what trick next; Fortune is pleased to be very merry with me to day, I find I have made a very pretty hand o' this matter;— Lost both my Mistresses, wrong'd a vertuous Lady, abus'd my Friend, and brought a Quarrel upon me, all in one quarter of an hour,— Hark'ee, Friendly,—

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: 'Tis as thou say'st, I do lie; and prithee forgive me for it.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: 'Tis very well, Sir;— But do you think this will satisfie me?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: At present I hope it will; to Morrow thou shalt know more.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: In the mean time then pray make some amends to the Lady.

sp.speaker: Wood,
sp.p: I can only ask her pardon, what else is requisite do thou do for me, anon when the Curtains are drawn.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Fear not, Sir; you shan't be troubl'd with any Night-work of mine.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: That I shou'd have both my Eyes, and yet not see these pair of Counterfeit Knaves; well, 'tis not the first time that Whoremongers and Adulters have been cloak't with the Law and the Gospel.
My Dear, art thou ventur'd hither too?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ay, my Dear, to fetch thee home, hearing Hob was well and abroad, I cou'd no longer bear to have you here, since I have recover'd health enough to be happy with you at home.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: What say'st thou?— Health,— and be happy?— What do'st thou mean, ha!— Shall I have thee in my Arms? And wil't thou be my Bride to Night?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I shall be what you please to have me.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Why then let sorrow vanish, and a Fig for my Daughter, Friendly, take her, and do what thou will't with her.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir; and to deserve this Kindness; if you get an Heir to Inherit your Estate, you shall have it again.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Hum! Do you jeer an Old Man? Well, if I can't get an Heir, do you, I'm contented now, it shou'd be for my Grandson.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: How now Ned, engaging afresh? If you purchase there, it must be for Life.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: With all my heart;— Madam, shall I have Possession upon that Condition?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I don't know what may be, after seven Years Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: He'll be worn out in half that time, Madam, if you don't reclaim him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Do you think it's possible, Sir, to reclaim him?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I hope so, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: So do I, tho' I doubt it; Neice have a care of him.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Let her take care of her self; her Father left her at my disposal, and if she Marries him, I won't give her a Groat.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Then, Sir, I suppose your Courtships at an end; for without that Charm, my Beauty, I fear, will have but little force.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Enough, Madam, to make me a Convert, if you dare put me to a Tryal— (Aside.)— I know not whether Infected by Friendly's Example, or any conceal'd Mischief in this holy Covering, but I find my self of a sudden strangely enclin'd to do something to repent of, as well as the foolish part of Mankind.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: I know she loves him, and if I thought he lov'd her,—

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: You need not doubt it, if he Marries her, for nothing but Love can make him do such a Violence to himself. [Aside to Woodvil.] Ned, pursue your purpose, if 'tis honourable for such a Beauty, and eight thousand Pound,— (if we can work the old fellow to consent) will be a better Fortune then any thou can'st hope for in Flanders.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: If Love goes on as it begins, I shall be of thy Opinion Frank.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Ask what thou wilt, my Dear, I will deny thee nothing; for thou art every thing to me; What would I give now, that it were Bed time, Neighbour, ha

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.p: Not so much as your Lady wou'd give to have it Morning again; for we old Fellows, Sir Thomas, are but troublesome Companions between a pair of Sheets.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Say you so, Sir; you may be mistaken; what say'st thou my dear?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I hope so too, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Ha! My little Rogue.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why shou'd I be angry that he cannot love me? I wou'd not love him if I cou'd help it: Shall I then think that a Crime in another, I wou'd my self be guilty of; Alas, 'tis neither of our faults; for fate has decreed me wretched to make him happy, and this way it must be done;— Neice to Day I am Sir Thomas, and your Fortune now you shall receive from my Gift,— take it, and dispose of it with yourself, as you please.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Madam, I shou'd blush so to receive it, if I did not hope you wou'd command both it and me.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: If I do, it shall be to bestow you here;— I know your Inclinations.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Madam, this generous Act has—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Deserv'd better usage than you have treated me with; but I forgive you, and hope I shall forget you too.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Never, Madam; for tho' I cannot as a Lover, as a Friend I'll hope to deserve a place in your Memory.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: A Friend! A cold distinction for a heart like mine, unless it cou'd degenerate, and be as yours has been to me; however be happy, and if I have contributed any thing to make you so, 'twill please me that I had it in my Power.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: That both these young Jades shou'd get the better of me!

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Aye, and you may thank Heav'n for't, or we had hang'd you; for Hob's Life depended upon your good Behaviour; and had you been still refractory, we had knock't out his Brains and you shou'd a Swung for't.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: A very Christian-like Contrivance.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: 'Twas such as wou'd a serv'd our turns, Sir.

sp.speaker: Jayl.
sp.p: There's Master Friendly.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: God bless you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: O, honest Hob!

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: What, durst that Rogue venture hither? Give me my Sword, I'll have a Collop of him I'm resolv'd.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Will you?— As I hope to be sav'd— Master Friendly— For the Lord sake do'nt let e'n draw his Sword upon me agen, pray now don't.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: No, no, prithee don't fright thy self;— Good Sir, let me intreat for him.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Don't ye thirst after Blood so, don't ye;— You have enough of mine to answer for already.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: What brought him here?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Brought me here?— Why look'ee, Sir, I am through Providence here a going to be Marry'd to Mary; and I don't know how it may please God to deal with me; therefore I desire before I go to Church, that I may be at Peace with all the World; forgive me, and I'll forgive you.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Poor fellow, he's the first I ever knew in his Condition that seem'd to have a sence of it.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: Well, since you will have it so, let him give us a Dance, and I will be Friends with him.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: And the Farm next his Father's, for his Life shall be his, if he makes a good Husband;— 'Tis in my Gift yet, Sir.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: And shall be ever so, Madam; and to show I'm pleas'd with your Bounty, I will stock it for him.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: O Lord, Scratch, strike up Scratch—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: And I'll make one.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Nay then we'll all joyn.
sp.stage: Enter Country People with a Fidler Playing before 'em.
sp.p: Hey-day! What's here the Country come in upon us?

sp.speaker: Sir Tho.
sp.p: So much for Dancing, now, my Dear, let's Home; for since this proves not a Tenement for Life, I don't care how soon I get hence.

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: And where shall we go?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: To Church, Madam, and then—

sp.speaker: Flo.
sp.p: E'en where you please;

l.hi: Marriage makes us yours, but remember still

sp.l: To keep us so, Women must have their Will;

l.hi: For by restraining us, you'll only prove
There's no Obedience, where the Tye's not Love.
